Update: Blech, I would recommend avoiding the green tea cream puff.  It leaves a nasty, almost medicinal aftertaste.
author: DD B.

description:
WARNING! Do Not Eat Chocolate Cream Puff...while Driving!

Holy cow! I have never been a fan of the cream puff family but, I gotta say I just had to see what all the crazy 250++ reviews were about. 

I picked mine up and decided to eat while driving....bad idea! The first bite was consummed while driving on mission to 4th....and yikes!! Talk about a not so wise thing to do. Not only was the chocolate cream everywhere...the taste sent me into a place lets...say for women...its a happy place. (smiles)

Next time I will pick these up if my girlfriends needs a little pick me up. Forget sex in the city.....chocolate cream puffs are a sure thing, safer, cleaner and cheaper!!
author: Kristina A.

description: This was the first time I tried a Beard Papa cream puff.  What can I say?  The holiday eating frenzy came over me.  I certainly enjoyed its light and airy-ness.  The fact that it wasn't heavy, and SO simple, made it a very nice little sweet snack.
author: Tamar D.

description:
The lines outside this place made me wonder what I was missing out.  Puffs, eh?

I went with my brother one day when we were hitting up a bunch of museums and galleries in the area one Saturday. I mentioned I wanted to try one of their puffs since it seems like everyone loves these things.

So we ordered a vanilla bean one and $2.25 later ... meh.  Am I missing something? Did I order the wrong flavor? Didn't do a damn thing for me.  I've had my fair share of cream puffs, but I really don't get what all the lines outside this place are for. Please tell me because I must be totally out of the loop.  I'd rather get some frozen one or buy some ice cream from Walgreens for $2.25.

Oh well, maybe it needed some chocolate swirl in it to add flavor.  More puffs for everyone else.  I'll pass.
author: imelda j.

description:
This is the best beard papa's in the bay area solely based on quality of the puffs and nothing else.
Its a tiny location and crowded with quite a wait but its worth it.
Watch out though cause you can easily spend $30 on a box of treats!
We came in for a half dozen puffs in chocolate and vanilla, half dozen petit-cro in chocolate, butter and cheese (think danish) and a cheesecake stick.
In Berkeley, you can get a half dozen at a flat price and it doesn't matter the shell or the filling but NOTE here you can't...to get the cookie shell it costs more...Also it costs more to get flavored petit-cro but she still let us get 2 of each and gave us an extra cheesecake stick for free to make up for the weirdness of ordering...
We will be back every time we pass through here!
And it's true: there is no weird depression on the bottom or strange rubber consistency like the berk location has!
author: J A M.

description:
Beard Papa. What a funny name for a very tasty treat. (Screaming "I love Beard Papa!" at the top of my lungs, to me, implies I love leather daddies.)

I've been to the BP in NYC--I can't wait for their new location in SF to open on May 12th.

If you're frantically searching for directions, note that Google/Yahoo/Mapquest don't have "Yerba Buena Lane" listed. (doubletrue.) YBL is behind the Four Seasons Hotel, between Market and Mission Streets.

Go forth and enjoy cream puffs!!
author: Richie K.

description:
I heard there are other locations but this is the only one I've been to, and i love it! It's always been busy whenever I've visited, so sometimes you have to wait in line for 5-10 minutes. But it's cheap, delicious and definitely worth the wait :) 

One of the best things to do on a summer afternoon - get thee some cream puffs (chocolate, vanilla and strawberry are the staples) and/or some of the other desserts there (mochis, cheesecake etc), and a cup of coffee, and then head across to Yuerba Buena gardens to relax and enjoy the sun!
author: Simika K.

description:
great cream puffs. Light and not deadly sweet. Just had the double chocolate (dark chocolate on top with chocolate filling. wonderful. though the dark chocolate melts if you put your fingers on it)

I went on a Tues at 3pm and there was no wait at all.

Clean bathroom. Friendly staff.

Thank gawd there is one here now (before had to go to NY or LA) but actually perhaps not so good b/c I will be gaining lots of weight!

Friday before closing, they ran out of eclairs in the afternoon. wah.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
Are you craving something cold, messy, and sweet? Then head on over to Beard Papa's!!! I end up eating every morsel of cream puff goodness! it never gets old. I especially love it on hot summer days cause the instant "pow" the cream gives when i take the first bite is amazing. 

it reminds me of childhood, when getting messy was ok and desserts were eaten before the meal.
author: Suzan L.

description:
UPDATE 6/23/06: I tried the green tea cream puffs and they are SO GOOD! Tied with vanilla in my book. And if you're in the mood for chocolate, get the double chocolate eclair, much better than just getting the plain chocolate puff. In the span of 4 days, I've paid Papa 3 visits. I see him more than I see my own dad!

UPDATE 6/2/06: Chocolate cream puffs are now available, but the vanilla ones taste way better, and plus they're 20 cents cheaper.

I learned my lesson the first time I went here and had to walk away empty-handed because the wait was too long. This time, I called Beard Papa and asked them what their wait time was. 

"There's no one in line right now."

"What?! Ok, I'll be right there!" 

I hung up the phone and ran out of my office with my coworker, collecting money from others on the way. We practically ran over there, which was actually smart because when we got there, there was only 1 person in front of us. We placed our order and stepped aside. In seconds, 10 people had lined up behind us. When we got our yellow box of cream puffs, we brought them outside and proceeded to indulge in these heavenly puffs. We looked like 2 kids eating with powdered sugar all over our lips and chins. The puff was not warm, but I didn't mind the vanilla custard inside being chilled. It's probably not worth a wait longer than 10 minutes, but it's good enough that you can't just eat one in a sitting.
author: Connie C.

description:
It's right next to St. Patricks, the old brick church... where you can go to pray for your soul after committing the heinous sin of gluttony at Beard Papa's.  I had a bit of an adventure finding the place. It's listed as on Yerba Buena Ln, so naturally I thought it would be somewhere around the Park.  Not.

The cream puffs go real well with any of their hot teas and coffees... which are also VERY good.  I had the special of the week which was Caramel cream, and by recommendation from a worker, a chocolate eclaire, which I enjoyed alot more being a big fan of chocolate syrup that shells at room temperature.  

Note: if you're consuming your cream puff on the go, esp on the way to work or a date, make sure you wear a bib and check the mirror after you're done eating-- you might want to wipe off that dollop of custard cream filling on your chin, unless, of course, this is your attempt at saving it as a snack for later.
author: Marjorie B.

description:
On my way home, I bought 4 vanilla cream puffs, one for each of us for dessert.  Since I have never tasted BP's puffs before and heard that they have to be eaten right away, to be fair, I decided to take one small bite of one now and save the rest to eat with the family.  I remember the first bite - it was orgasmic, ethereal, sublime.  WOW!   I remember putting the remaining puff back in the box.  

Then nothing.

The next thing I know, I'm sitting on the bus with a box of only 3 cream puffs on my lap, powder sugar and smears of cream all over my shirt.  

The kids can split one.
author: mia s.

description:
For dessert we bough some these before heading to dinner. Fluffy as air pastry puffs filled with creamy chocolate or vanilla bean filling. These babies are so soft could seriously shove a whole one your mouth (it was a dare!). Thank goodness these are located in downtown SF or else id be here everyday
The molten chocolate cake is scrumptious! Best when heated so when you take a slice, the smooth chocolate flows out. At around $3 each I'd suggest getting your own, after one bite you're not going to be sharing.
author: Lola L.

description:
Wow.  Today is my lucky day.  Not only did I finally get to try one of these cream puffs, but it literally walked up to my desk (thanks, Chris!).  Wow again.  Light, flaky pastry (not too sweet) and a satiny, creamy delicious filling.  Can I get an "Amen?"  Hallelujah!  Praise Papa!

Now I want MORE...  Uh, Chris...?
author: Andi T.

description:
Lesson from wise chinese friend #1

I was completely stuffed after eating in chinatown with my chinese friend, Ke. (You know how that goes. and if you don't, find a chinese friend.) 

Ke is the only girl I know that can eat as much and as often as I do. We were both stuffed. But then we walked by Beard Papa. 

Ke says: "We must eat a cream puff. 

I say: "But Ke, I'm so full."

Ke says: "Grasshopper, there is always room for cream puffs."

Ok, I made up that last line, but I did learn from Ke that there is always room for the edible, hand-held heaven from Beard Papa.
author: Kathryn T.

description:
Well, my gram has been making cream puffs since as far back as I remember. Beard Papa are most deinetely of high caliber, but they are no grandma puff.

After doing extensive research on Beard Papa, i was bouncing up and down ready for the puff experience. So we get there, wait a mere 10 mins and buy a 6 pack of puff. The guy behind the counter relieves us by giving the EPWT (Estimated Puff Wait Time). You can tell he has probably had hyped customers follow him home...he already has the 'Time to Make the Donuts' kinda lackluster umph.

The puffs were good. not 45 minute wait good. Though, I'll be back to try the other flavors. I intend for Thanksgiving 2006 to be the season of the Pumpkin-flavor Puff. Giant Puff will replace Turkey!
author: Nicole L.

description:
He is my papa, ok nvm my dad does not have a beard. Beard Papa's is papa of cream puffs, they were delectable! I stood in line yesterday and had to turn away since it was taking too long so I diligently returned today and there was no line at 7:30pm. No green tea or chocolate cream yet, it says Coming Soon....

Update: Tried green tea, caramel but missed the strawberry.....I will be back! Hasta La Vista, Baby!

Update: I've tried green tea, caramel, pumpkin, vanilla and chocolate. Will have to try strawberry and Milk tea to complete the quest! :)
author: Yan M.

description:
I don't see what the big deal is about these things.  I've had them a few times, and I just can't fathom why anybody would wait in some ridiculously long line for them.  I've had them here, at the one in the mall, and even in their home country of Japan outside of a train station in Tokyo (where there was also a short line for the freshies).  They smell damn good fresh, but that's about it.

It's a novel idea, and they're not horrible/inedible, but to me, it's the same as getting a tub of Cool hwhip (yeah, hwhip - hwhat's wrong hwhith that?), and taking a big ole spoonful or two and shoving that in your mouth.  The choux pastry has no taste (at least not any that's discernible from the glob of sugary cream and powdered sugar - and chocolate if you got the "eclair").  Maybe it's just me.  

Anyways, if you go to the one in the mall on a weekend afternoon, be prepared for a huge line.  Other times, it's quite manageable, if there's a line at all.
author: T C.

description:
I was just coming from a dental appointment where I had received my first ever local anesthetic on my lower jaw.

Of course, me being the bastard that I am, I  decided to show my dentist who was boss - How dare he tell me too much sugar? I'll show him somedaaaaaayyyyy....hey?! What this? Beard Papa's? Creampuffs? I'm in!

Some 3 minutes later, I'm seated at a table outside eating my creampuff bonanza, with half of it actually making it into my mouth, while the other half is actually sliding out of my mouth down my numbed-out jaw and onto my clothes. Totally oblivious, I'm pigging out until I see the stares and look down at myself. I'm sure my reaction should have been complete horror, but instead I started laughing hysterically making me look all the more insane to the tourists passing by.

Ahhhh....good times, Beard Papa, good times.
author: Nick R.

description:
Honestly, I don't get it. Are people drawn to this for the novelty of the name as much as they are the product itself? Does their goofy logo, looking like some bastard lovechild of the Gorton's Fisherman and KeroKeroKeroppi, hold some sort of supernatural sway over young Asian women and the manga obsessed 16-year old white guys who love them? Or is it that Beard Papa is the Japanese version of Cinnabon? (BINGO! These things are in or around some of the bigger/busier train stations in Japan and, just like Cinnabon, you can smell them a mile away.)

I've had Beard Papa cream puffs in Japan, Singapore and now San Francisco, and they tasted the same. Which is to say, the pastry has the texture (and taste, if any) of fluffy cardboard, (Ah! You say, but it's finely crafted Japanese cardboard! JAPAN = SUPERIOR TECHNOLOGY! Sorry, I lived there a while, I ain't buying it.) and the custard just squishy glop.

At least they're not excessively sweet, but to my mind they're also not worth the calories. Nor the hype.
author: Ian K.

description:
Beard Papa is a chain operation originally from Osaka, Japan (BTW the original location in Osaka is Five Stars). They franchise their locations all over the world. 

Because it is a franchise some locations are better than others and some have more variety of flavors. Depending on how well capitalized the franchisee is the quality of the location, decor and freshnest of the Cream Puffs. In addition to the Osaka location I have been to the few in San Francisco and Los Angeles. This one in on Yerba Buena Lane is one the best out of the LA and San Francisco. 

The original flavor Vanilla is my favorite; Chocolate and Green Tea come in second. Beard Papa's Cream Puffs are probably the Best Commercial made that I have eatten. I would indulge myself more if it wasn't so rich in calories and fat (about 220 each) I can tell you if you love Cream Puffs - you need to try Beard Papa.
author: David H.

description:
I tried Beard Papa once at this little underground food market in Singapore, and I was SO in heaven- crispy on the outside, soft in the inside,creamy and delectable . So when I heard that they were opening a store in San Francisco, I almost shat in my pants.

I drove out there, and ordered a HUGE box of cream puffs, expecting to fill that little hole that was created in my heart when I left Singapore... and then I cried, because the freaking cream puffs SUCK here.  And they were cold and stale!!!!
author: Stephanie L.

description: Whenever I come out of church praying, I can imagine heaven smelling like the outside! Ew gross! No, seriously it smells like fresh bakes cream puffs! Yum! Love them! I always get the eclaire cream puff. I love the chocolate on the outside! I always get vanilla cream, but the strawberry cream is my fav! I have taken a bite out of others' chocolate filled ones and it is pretty good as well. One of my friends loves getting the cocoa puff.
author: Reese E.

description: Okay, so I have to admit I have absolutely nothing to compare to my B. Puffy experience--really not a lot of fried foods where I grew up.  I bought a few (chocolate, vanilla, and eclair with vanilla) and brought them in to work for my co-workers to sample.  I think the consensus was that the chocolate puff was the best of the three, perhaps because the puff itself tasted most fresh, sort of eggy like a popover.  Yum.
author: Cassidy P.

description:
I was excited!
I wanted to fall head-over-heels in love & return again & again.
I wanted to be S P R U N G!
I waited in line(not long).
I breathed in the enticing aroma.
I watched repeatedly the stupid "sf beard papa arrival" loop were the man of large girth gets a cream shot of goodness all over his face.
But alas,
I am lactose intolerant and the yummy vanilla puff was murder on my tummy.
Hmmm, maybe it was the that+the 2 pints of Hefeweizen  vying for supremacy in a vat of gastric juices.
Whatever! pack the peptol bismol 'cause I'll be back to place the green tea puff on my tongue very soon. . .
author: Kia B.

description:
I don't know what to say that would be different than anyone else.

Beard Papa originated from Osaka, Japan in 1999 that expanded internationally because of its popularity.

I love Beard Papa's cream puffs - green tea, vanilla, and chocolate being my top favorites.  

I would rate it 5, except I'm not a huge fan of its other products.  The cheesecake is adorable and good to eat, but not as great as the cream puff.  Another is the Fondant Au Chocolate - though delicious - was also not as delicious as it could have been.
author: Nina M.

description:
I finally tried one of these bad boys (courtesy of Michael M), and it was pretty tasty...the innards are more like custard than whipped cream though, which was unexpected and a bit disappointing.

My rating may change after I actually visit their store and sample some of their other offerings (I only had their standard cream puff).

I think their logo is kinda funny...looks more like a fisherman than someone who bakes cream puffs...what's up with that?
author: Art D.

description:
*bite* *chewchewchew* mmmmmmmmmmmm...mmmmMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMmmmmmmmmmm.....ohohohhhhhhhhhhhhyessssssssssssssssssssssss....

I just had an oralgasm...

Yeah, they're that good.

I think I need a cigarette now.
author: Christy L.

description:
Well, this is definitely the best cream puff I've ever had. The flavor of the weeks are also delicious - not to sweet, just right. I didn't like the chocolate cream though because it tasted powdery to me. Maybe it was just a bad batch? The cheese cake stick was just a regular cheesecake, but not as sweet.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
Really what is the big deal about this place.  I had more than one friend tell me I HAVE to try these cream puffs.  So I go what's so special about a cream puff?  I had them before, wasn't too impressed.  My friend goes, "no you really HAVE to try these, it's so much better."

The last time someone told me that in those precise words happened to be when Krispy Kreme was the rave circa 2002 or somewhere around there.  At that time, this person swore up and down it was unlike any other doughnut I'd ever had.  I tried the Krispy Kreme, was none too impressed and went on my merry way.  Krispy Kreme today is eating crow and closing down shops, too big too quick.

Back to Beard Papa, I tried the chocolate and the vanilla.  I wasn't too impressed and for the life of me couldn't figure out how this place gets so busy.  The filling is bland of reminds of refined pudding.  In fact the people in the back were probably whipping up a fresh batch of Jell-O when they saw the line start to get long.  I didn't finish mine and chastised myself for wasting my calories on something I didn't care for.  

Is this like a Krispy Kreme trend of old?  I wouldn't be surprised to see old Beard ride his ship on out of here in a few years once people get cream puff fatigue.
author: Bill P.

description:
Ok so after seeing this multiple times I finally decided to give it a shot. I guess for mainly just making creme puffs they are pretty succesful. So after my sandwich that I grabbed down the street from A.G Ferrari's I decided to pick up some dessert for my sweet tooth. 

I took a look at the different things they had in the menu and I wasn't really feeling their creme puffs. So I settled with the brownie looking cake with chocolate icing in the middle. I had asked them to warm it for me so that when i get to it it'll still be warm. So after my meal and chompin on some onions from the sandwich I knew that this would be a great compliment to change may pallette. After about 20 minutes it was still warma dn the filling was also still pretty wam. I bite into it and immediately I remember the chocolate icing on the Goldilocks's cakes. So I guess that was the best part, but I definitely think that if they were a bit cheaper it would be most coveted.  SO 3 stars for me
author: Justin G.

description:
OVER-RATED!

Whoever would wait in line for more than 5 minutes here is out of their mind.  While these are tasty, they're not much better than a regular cream filled doughnut from Dunkin' on the east coast.  And at Dunkin, they're a third of the price and you can get a savory ice coffee (and possibly a tug job in the parking lot too).  Winner - Dunkin Donuts!
author: Rob K.

description:
I'm just not that into it.

I don't doubt that the quality and the actual taste of these cream puffs aren't good but I just don't think I'm that into them.

The custard is too runny and the cream puff didn't amaze me.

Don't know what exactly it is but I think I'm the only person who's not on board.
author: Winnie L.

description:
I give Papa's puffs three stars only because they're so much better at their original locations in Asia. First time I had one was in the Wanchai MRT station in Hong Kong. 

It was after work and I was blindly following the queue.  I then realized that I was in the wrong line. Apparently I was next for some cream puffs! So, when in Hong Kong, do as the Hong Kongers do - I bought six and ate five, gave the last one to a homeless guy, and barfed up three. But they were fantabulous! The puffs were warm and crisp and the cream, smooth and chilled, was not "injected" until purchase.

When I came back to the States, I was ecstatic to learn that NYC had a Beard Papa's. So I flew there and bought another six. But they were all cold and stale! Yuck. Apparently in the States they prepare the puffs ahead of time, in anticpiation of the crowds. Preparation my hiney. I want my puffs fresh! I puked up five and gave one to a homeless guy.   Oh well...
author: Peter S.

description:
Allowed myself a rightful dab of custard before handing it over to a cohort.....and perusing the positive reviews, i have to add that it absolutely did not make me reevaluate my terms on teat abuse. This fell WAY short of a prostate tickle like i had hoped.

The extra star is more of an acknowledgement for people who've probably purchased it right when it opens, no qualms with direct flirtation with obesity and the aura of conglomerate decadence during the dawn of the initial mandible pounce: scalding; viscous waves of tactically instigated, heaven-churned embryo and blanco-pigmented blood swirling down their clamoring cake holes like a 90 year old thigh in a sauna and the recognition of a 1.75 well spent. People= ick festival on wheels. 

Dr. Hibbert= "UHHH HUH HUH HUH!"
author: Christopher J.

description:
I like these cream puffs.

But there is no way in hell that i'll wait in line more than thirty minutes for these.

Ya'll craze.
author: Richard T.

description:
So I was at a house warming party in So. Cal this weekend and someone brought some Beard Papa's Cream Puffs.  I remember reading a review or two about them on Yelp and thought, "Hey, cool!  I can actually try one now."  2 bites later, the thing was completely devoured and I was hunting for more.  This is what a crack fiend must feel like.

Later on that night, I went to an event at the Hollywood Bowl.  On my way there, I passed by the Kodak Theatre shopping area where low and behold, they had a Beard Papa's store!  I ran in and bought a 12 pack that contained the Vanilla, Chocolate, and Milk Tea flavors.

Now let me pause here for a moment.  When it comes to traveling and the extra security measures, I'm pretty patient, figuring that the important thing is that I arrive safely at my destination.  I need to get to the airport early?  No problem.  Need me to practically strip down to nothing at the security gate?  No problem.  Can't carry on anything that is even remotely liquid like?  No problem...that is, until I can't bring a box full of Beard Papa's cream puffs just because of the delicious and creamy filling!!!  NOW YOU TERRORISTS HAVE GONE TO @$%@#e%!#$%  !#$%!q-ING FAR!!!

Luckily, when I went to write this review, I now see that there is a store in SF!  

Score:  Dessert loving fiends: 1, Terrorists: 0
author: Brian L.

description:
I walked by one day and noticed the bright yellow writing on the glass in front. I waited anxiously for opening day to come. Opening day was crazy!!! The line was out the door and down the block. They were handing out samples. I wasn't about to wait in line for that long and decided to come back when things died down a bit. 

They had a promotion going on that first week. Buy 20 cream puffs and get a free thermos. I asked about the thermos and they ran out. I was a lil' disappointed so the guy gave my girlfriend and I a charm for our cell phone. That was nice of him to do that.  

When I tasted that first puff.....oh my!!!! It was sooooo good. It wasn't too sweet. It was perfect!!!! I went back each week to taste all the other flavors. Their flavored cream puffs are "Rotating on a weekly basis". I like all of them except the chocolate one. It tasted funny to me. My favorite is green tea and milk tea. The milk tea puff is available in San Francisco only. The coffee one is available in Redwood City only. 

They have cheesecake sticks for $1.25. It was good but not as good as a regular cheesecake. 

The Fondant Au Chocolat ($2.25) is mouthwatering!!! It's not too sweet either. 

The eclairs cost a little bit more than the cream puffs. I'm not very fond of them. To me, they look exactly like a cream puff except the puff part of the eclair is more dry. And the taste is.....bleh.  This may be only me though.

They had really long lines during the day time and after work for about 6 months. After that, you can just walk in any time of day and wait in line for a few minutes. 

On their website you can see the flavors of the week for San Francisco. I've included a link below.

http://www.beardpapasf.com/flavors_sf.htm 

Go get your puff on!!!!!

EDIT 8/8/07: Just went in and saw they have gotten rid of the milk tea flavor cream puff and replaced it with tiramisu. NOOOO!!!! I really liked the milk tea one. *sob*
Cream puffs! Love 'em. I foresee that Beard Papa is the next Krispy Kreme. You'll probably see them in your town soon. I hope they come to the South Bay!
author: Jon M.

description:
One of my co-workers brought in some of these overfilled, too sweet, and quite chalky custard concoctions.  

I have to say that after the creamy explosion and a forest of napkins, I managed to finish one.

Even as a freebie, I will have to pass.
author: Dakar D.

description:
I hate movie ads. Despise them. Want to throw things at the screen when I see them. But this ONE time, I'm actually glad I was paying attention. I saw cream puffs, heavenly, fluffy cream puffs. I ran outside, across the street, and found Beard Papa's. Closed. Bastards. I stood with my fingers pressed against the glass, watching the "making of" video as they stepped through the long and difficult process of making the cream puffs and filling.

And last weekend, ahhhhhhh. Finally. Well worth the wait. I got 6, expecting to space them out over the next few days. Not a chance. Such fluffy, crispy pastry. Such creamy and sweet chocolate and vanilla oozing out the end, leaking across my fingers. I tossed down 2.5 right on the premises, shared the other .5 with my partner, then took the last 3 to the movie. Within 5 minutes of the film, I was picking crispy little crumbs from the bottom of the box and licking the paper in which they were wrapped.

I want more. But I mustn't. These things are dangerous.
author: Justin W.

description: They should probably outlaw these - given the chance I could probably bring harm to myself by over indulging.  I though the idea of a store that sells cream puffs would be destined to fail - I mean how many can you sell?  Well, try them and you'll see.
author: Eric G.

description:
It's near the church i use to go to!

I absolutely love Beard Papas.  We order a dozen :]  i know quite the fatty! I love love the vanilla and chocolate.  We ordered the strawberry filled one, but personally I thought it was alright.  I'll stick to the original and simple flavors of vanilla & choco.  We also got a cookie topping puff instead of the originally breading?  so it had pieces of cookies crumbles on it! I recommend that if you're a cookie maniac.

i been here recently & was surprised that it wasn't quite busy as before..maybe it was the time of day? or maybe every ones going to the one on market now, you know in SF shopping center (do they still call it that?).
author: Jacqueline D.

description:
It definitely feels a little cultish in the way only Japanese-run franchises can - the immaculate machines, the impossibly white walls, the broadly smiling order-taker, the silent puff-makers, the smug and slightly shifty look on Beard Papa's 1-dimentional face - you almost expect a little theme song to be piped in "Cream Puffs, Cream Puffs, eat them up, yum..."

Blessedly, the line was only about 6 people deep because of the downpour that had just occured, so I begged my man to stop the car because I needed to try the cream puffs RIGHT NOW (using the element of surprise/insanity to catch him off guard so he couldn't say no)

Even he had to admit, they're REALLY good (I love it when I'm right). 

Flaky, tasty pastry outside.  Usually, cream puff pastry tastes like plastic to me, so, well done.

Smooth, lovely vanilla custard filling.  The filling is the kicker.  It's edible, it's drinkable, hell, it's wearable!

Warning:  if you are wearing dark clothing, after you hoover your cream puff (or 2, or 3) with its generous dusting of powdered sugar, you will look like you took a dive head first into a big pile of coke, a la Scarface.  Come to think of it, you will feel that way too, as you are immediatel elated, but then you just want more and you can't stop thinking about the next one.

I'm a little bit scared that Beard Papa is going to come to me in my dreams and tell me that I need to buy one every day for the rest of my life ("don't worry, little one, lactose intolerance & adult diabetes will make you special, that's all!"), but it won't stop me from going back.  And now you, too must go.  Papa knows best.
author: Liz S.

description:
As you walk up, a sweet eggy aroma envelopes you... Luckily, at 2:30pm on a Weds, there were only 5 people in line. 

They are scrumptious and not too sweet - just the perfect crispy, light textured puff with the most sublime cream inside.  

I ordered one with no cream to check out the flavor of the pringle, and it also is awesome just by itself...  The texture reminds me of roasted marshmallow 'skins' - where you roast the outer layer and then sliiiiide it off, eat it, and then roast the next layer...  (you know what I mean, right??)  Soft in the inside, light and crunchy in places on the outside.  Hard to explain.  Very tasty liddle morsels.

And best thing - Ate two and feel light as a feather.... No oil on your fingers and no sugary aftertaste.  all natural satisfaction.  la la laaaaaa!
author: Melanie C.

description:
From When Harry Met Sally:

"Women can't fake it"
"Yes, they can"
"No they can't" 

*Sally does her famous faking orgasm scene*

Woman in diner:

"I'll have what she's having."

Well, that just about summed up my experience at Beard Papa's.   Cream puffs so good... you get the idea.
author: Sloane R.

description:
I don't get it.

These puffs were good but are not even remotely worth the wait. What is up with the glacially slow production line Beard Papa? There were maybe 15 people in front of us and it took us a good 30-40 minutes to get our cream puffs. Now imagine how long it would take for Happy Donuts to serve 15 people. Or Mitchell's Ice Cream, for that matter.

Get it together, Papa!
author: Bart C.

description:
Just what I need, yet another way to avoid being healthy and slim and all. 

But color me happy, with powered sugar all over my chin, and sticky custard cream all over my fingers.

Funnily enough, I actually really liked the green tea flavour, but then again, I'm one of those people who tries the japanese food that scares my friends silly. Next time, though, I need to go on the week they have caramel. MMMMMmmmmmm!!!!
author: Paula W.

description: Cream puffs -- now, I have my favorites from Trader Joe's, Costco and Fantasia in South Bay.  Who would have guess that SF finally has their version of "FRESH" cream puffs.  I must say the light texture bread almost like a croissant that wraps around the very delicious and light vanilla bean cream is just simply delicious!
author: pengrin ..

description: Oh. My. God. BF dragged us in here after beers next door at the 4th Street bar. I couldn't believe he'd try to kill our buzz but jeezus the chocolate cream puffs are unreal. Better not be on a diet if you come here. And even if you are, hell, don't be such a pansy. Live it up once in a while.  And as for me, I wish there were more once's in whiles. Beard Papa, come to mama. Check my photo contribution.
author: Michelle G.

description: The cream puffs are great. Just make sure before you leave with a take out box you check whats inside. Totally wrong. Whats so hard..they had one customer and the only thing they got right was the number of items. I ordered one puff with vanilla, one eclair with vanilla (for hubby) and two cheesecake sticks. Instead i got two puffs with coffee flavor..allergic to coffee, one tiramisu reeking of coffee and one chocollate molton...is it that hard to getnit right?  How about have the person who makes up the order read back to you what is in the box so you dont get all the way home to find out you cant eat anything in your order
author: M O.

description:
YUMMY!!! The pastry is delicious, the cream is creamy and sweet and just so heavenly. My hubby and I each got an original vanilla bean cream puff and our bill was $4.50. They were a good size!

I would definitely go back!
author: Audra M.

description:
So, I expected these things to be a little smaller and ordered six (to share) without really looking to see what they were. Apparently they MUST be eaten within 24 hours or they turn into pumpkins, so I've now eaten three in 18 hours and I think my belly is turning to jelly, very happy jelly.

+vanilla
+eclair
-strawberry (too sweet, stick with vanilla)
author: Jessica H.

description:
Beard Papa's Vanilla Cream Puffs are so darn delicious!!!  

I couldn't resist this perfect blend of cream and puff that I HAD to stop by after getting my teeth squeaky cleaned.  Yes, my dentist probably won't like it.  But I just had to reward myself.

Ahh...how it satisfies...
author: Lisa L.

description: Try the fondant and the cream puffs.  Out of this world!!!!!
author: Ann S.

description:
What is it about cream puffs?  I mean, there are people that live and die for cream puffs.  Like my friend's mom who made a homemade cream puff TREE.  (Why a tree?)  Or heck, my mom who has been a loyal follower of the St. Honore cake from Delange Patisserie on Fillmore for the past 15 or so years.  Well, for you cream puffers out there,  Beard Papa's is your new friend.  

So the puffs are puffilicious - you heard that already.  But let me just say that there's nothing that annoys me more than an inefficient assembly line.  I went at 630pm, prime foot traffic time, and this was the division of labor: they had 1 person taking money, 1 person creaming the puffs, 1 person powdered sugaring the puffs, and 1 person boxing/bagging the puffs.  I stood in line for like 10 minutes, almost missing my bus just to pay.  And then the cashier guy, really nice guy don't get me wrong, hands me my change and a receipt - "your order number is 32" says he.  And literally 1.23 seconds later, the person boxing yells out 32.  Bottleneck much?

Perfect puffs, but that's minus one stars for operational ineifficiency.
author: Audrey T.

description:
Wow,  these things are good - I did not have to do anything to get one, so I cannot testify to service, value for money, or lengths of lines, etc,,, but man these are sooo good.

But you can tell why they are good... no indulgence is spared on the ingredients here... they are like an American cannoli... laced with thick chocolate, oozing with not-too-sweet custard, and flaking with crispy puff pastry. Soooo goood.

But then, COCAINE is good, CHOCOLATE for breakfast is good, TWINS are good -  and you know... you probably shouldn't oughta be doing any of them either!
author: Kingpin X.

description:
HOLLLLLLLER to the cream puff gods.  

This place is really great.  I've taken every person who visited me to Beard Papa's - and each person has totally loved this place. 

I'm partial to simple flavors like vanilla and chocolate.  I wish they'd make a chai flavor, would be so good!
author: Bhumika K.

description:
Good Lord these are good!!!! Bring on the Green Tea Puffs!!!!! To commemorate my experience, here is a Haiku:

Heavenly Cloud Puffs
How you flow with sweet goodness
My soul is complete.

Update 6/25/06:  THEY HAVE GREEN TEA PUFFS!!!!  They're damn good too!!!!
author: Marco M.

description:
I don't get it.

I'm no stranger to the cream puff...I used to get one every year at the Del Mar Fair, from a rickety cream puff stand.  But they were bigger, & the pastry tasted better, & they had both custard & whipped cream....

I got a chocolate cream puff at Beard Papa's & the filling was so disappointing...it was like drippy chocolate cake batter.  Which I ate every last bit of.  But ew.
author: Holly F.

description:
*jumping on bandwagon

Ok so you have to wait in line most of the time for some of these tasty morsels. It's worth it. Now at least you can go to the mall down the street and wait indoors for a Beard Papa. They are really good though. I remember seeing long lines in Rapongi wondering why people would wait so long for a cream puff then I tried one. Yup it's worth it. Did I say that it's worth it yet?? Don't buy just one and bring home some for friends. It's the Asian thing to do!
author: Johnny J.

description:
So finally I tried what everyone's been raving about...and as I was standing in line all I could think about is that scene from Van Wilder when they're...Umm...manipulating the dog to secrete it's manly secretions to use as filler for eclairs....

Image aside I thought the creme puffs were OK...didn't blow my pants off...i tried...i tasted...i probably won't come back since i did not care for them that much!!
author: Karen B.

description:
At some point in my life, I decided to give up on my waistline completely.  I'd rather have a tummy filled with yummy goodness than the overrated bikini body.  That's what one-piece suits and tankinis are for, right?

I first heard of this chain down in southern California, when my aunt brought some cream puff wonderfulness home.  At first I was like, Papa who??  Then I began to appreciate these pastries in all its glory.

Here's a challenge for you:  try eating one of their cream puffs or eclairs sans napkin, without spilling any or getting it all over your face and hands.  YOU CAN'T, CAN YOU?

Anyway, I digress.  This place is awesome.
author: Tori S.

description:
Green tea cream puff - puffalicious.  And messy.  Good messy, though.  

I like that they've got more than just vanilla now as I heard was the case when they opened - there's a different flavor every day of the week.  What's life without variety?
author: Kate M.

description:
I guess this is the In-n-Out of cream puffs.  My Japanese mother used to make them for me growing up so I've always loved them.  I finally tried Beard Papa and it was a bit different than Mom's but good too.  Since I'm not an afficianado of non Mom cream puffs, I'll leave this as four stars.

Mom's still get five!
author: Gene X.

description:
Based on the savory, crusty, flaky shell filled with oozing sweet, whipped cream that I licked so uncouthly off of the paper at my desk, given to me by a colleague ("here, Jess, have a Beard Papa Cream puff.  You won't get hooked.  I promise."), I am checking into 4 Winds Treatment Center.   

The Beard Papa cream puff- it's stronger than me.
author: Jessica M.

description:
My name is Phillip Wang and I am addicted to Beard Papa Cream Puffs

I usually buy a dozen for my family or friends but once i put that box down and we all open it up, I end up eating two or three?~?~~?

i dont know what they have in them cream puffs but im sure its not legal! 

Im pretty sure its not the Vanilla bean~
author: phillip w.

description:
REPENT!

This place is sinful, after having one you have to ask for forgiveness. haha these large ceam puffs the size of my fist puts me in a little happy fit for a good afternoon.
author: Janelle H.

description:
I knew this stuff was good when my boyfriend and I were fighting over who would get the last bite. I even went as far as to suck some of the vanilla cream out of the puff before I passed it over to him.

I told him to buy a dozen cream puffs...but nooooo! He thought we wouldn't be able to finish it all so we ended up with 1 chocolate, 1 strawberry, and 2 vanillas. We split a vanilla  when we got back to the car because we didn't want to eat too much before having dinner at House of Prime Rib and I wanted to enjoy my meat. 

The first bite was luscious! It was crispy on the outside and smooth and creamy on the inside. It wasn't too sweet--just the way I liked it. Unfortunately, I did inhale some of that powdered sugar. I wanted to save the cream puffs for the next day, but my boyfriend peer pressured me into eating them all with him. 

Now, 5 days later, he is still talking about those blasted cream puffs. He laments that he didn't get the dozen that I originally wanted. I can't even sleep at night anymore because he wakes me up and whispers "Beard Papa's" in my ear. Darn you Beard Papa's--you and your puffy, creamy, heavenly goodness.

Minus 1 star for being not hot and fresh out of the oven like I expected.
author: Kim N.

description:
If it wasn't for Beard Papa's I would never ever go to that boring ass mall. The line here doesn't get horribly long b/c the workers are very efficient at this location. They got this place set up like an assembly line but then again how hard is it to fill cream puffs with the right flavor?

My favorites are the vanilla and pumpkin flavored cream puffs. Chocolate and tiramisu are not all that. I felt that they were bland. The cheesecake sticks are not that great either. They were kinda dry and the taste was off somehow.

I'm not giving Beard Papa's 5 stars because they never have green tea cream puffs when I am there. People complain that they don't like the pudding texture of the cream but I like it just fine. I think that it tastes healthier and not as sweet as most cream puffs. The pudding recipe is actually common in Japan. I had similar cream puffs when I went to Sunshine City. 

Beard Papa is creepy.
author: becky s.

description:
I have a real problem with this place-it happens to be a block and a half away from my house.  

I first tried Beard Papa when I was in Manhattan in 2005, before it hit San Francisco.  How I longed for a BP near me...  be careful what you wish for.  Especially the strawberry flavor.  

If loving you is wrong, I don't want to be right.
author: Monica L.

description:
and still luvin' it... we now routinely do drive bys, where I drop someone off, and then circle around the block slowly until I can pick up said someone, delectable cream puffs in hand. 

you know what I'm talking about. because I wasn't the only person circling that block.
author: Sasha R.

description:
So I didn't exactly have to wait in a long line like more than half of you, and I'm so glad I didn't. I was in and out in about 5 minutes.

I bought two, just in case I did like it. The warm outside croissant-like crust covered in powdered sugar was nice and crisp, but the cool vanilla custard filling tasted like a huge wad of grease and butter. I ended up giving the 2nd one away. It was like eating two tablespoons full of butter. It gave me a headache and made me feel sluggish.

I checked this spot out based on Yelp reviews, but I just don't see what the hype is about. It's kinda like when Krispy Kreme Doughnuts first opened in the Bay Area and people drove miles just to get a box of hardened sugar. 

But I guess this'll do well with the tourists---there was a group of them taking "before and after" pictures of themselves eating a whole dozen of them. Good for them. I'll probably try a different flavor next time and see if I change my mind, but waiting in line for one is just silly.
author: Zell C.

description:
Can you say O-V-E-R-R-A-T-E-D

Well - I sure can.  I was pretty disappointed overall.  I mean they're fine creampuffs - like if i had heard nothing about this place and wandered in without reading 185 yelp reviews - i would have been content.  Happy to get a decent sugar fix with an equally opposite unhappy force from my conscience that realizes how many laps i'd have to swim to get the calories out of my system.  

So - don't make a special field trip to come here (not like my special field trips to Stella for tha cannolis)...but if there isn't a crazy line - feel free to stop by and add some laps to your planned swim tomorrow
author: D S.

description:
Heavenly cream puffs. 

I agree with Nellie M. 

You might want to avoid this place if you're trying to lose a couple of pounds.
author: Pamela B.

description: It's sweet and it's cheap. Need I say more? Order a dozen, just do it. Don't try to fool yourself into thinking you only want one or you're going to share with your anorexic friend. Feed the need.
author: Carlos A.

description:
Quite possibly the best cream puff in the world.  I had a chance to try a few out this past weekend.  The smell of the bakery was enough to get me excited over tasting these delicious pastries.  You have to try!

Van's Must tries : Green tea & pumpkin cream puffs
author: Van N.

description:
Pulled the pins on this truly whimsical Japanese import tonight and didn't have to wait long. About 6:15/6:20 on a Tuesday night. So it seems like everybody waiting 1/2 hr + for these just needs to plan a visit during off-peak hours. I had a vanilla and a green tea (the flavor of the week) puff less than 5 minutes from when I entered the shop. Both scrumptious. Pick one thing (in this case, the titular creampuffs) and do it properly. 

Five dreamy stars.

EDIT: I have since tried the chocolate and strawberry creampuffs and the eclair. The eclair is just a vanilla creampuff topped with a shell of chocolate, served cold. Not the best eclair I've had, but a tasty when graded as a creampuff. The chocolate creampuff was magic. The strawberry was kind of a drag actually. I mean I finished it and all, but it tasted not really of strawberries and the filling seemed thinner, more watery than the others .
author: Jeremy W.

description:
Okay, first of all if you think cream puffs -- of any kind -- could be orgasmic then... well, I'd say you need to go out and get a real date. These cream puffs are REALLY GOOD. And if you're only eating one: the eclairs are the puffs to go with.

As for the long lines? Blame the lame-O's behind the counter. Seriously, how hard is it to pick up a puff, jam it into the cream thing, sprinkle it with some powder, stuff it in a paper wrapper, and yell out "Joe!". To watch the morons behind the counter, you'd think they were handling uranium. It's bad when you start thinking, "maybe they should start recruiting workers from McDonald's."
author: L. M.

description:
Let's draw the similarities between Krispy Kremes and this place, shall we not?

+ When both landed in the Bay Area, they caused immediate ruckus rivaling that of the Beatles' arrival in the US.  People stood in line in the cold and hot to catch a glimpse of this phenomenon.  Even those skeptics were generally turned into fans through first taste.  

+ A Beard Papa cream puff boasts 230 calories per puff.  Though the original glazed donut from Krispy Kremes is not to be underestimated with 200 calories per holed delight.  Despite these nutritional errs, both places have succeeded in luring the health-conscious into denial through sugars and fair pricing.

+  Devouring these treats is no easy feat.  One oozes sugar; the other flakes and melts into stickiness.  Both a danger to your fingers, lips, chins, cheeks, and even your shirt.

+ You can smell both a least a block away.  The aroma of butter and sweet baked goodness serves as perfume to its neighbors.  Take the Beard Papa at Westfield shopping center for example...you can smell them from the 4th floor (although at first whiff, you wonder if McDonald's has infiltrated the mall and started making A LOT of eggs).  

+ Alas, however, both will begin to lose it's luster (actually, for KK's, it already has.  BP's just following in its footsteps...)  Lines are no more.  People walking around the street with boxes boasting from either of these chains are almost non-existent.  (You should have SEEN the streets of Downtown when the first Beard Papa opened up.  Couldn't go anywhere without being knocked around by a yellow box.)

But, since this is a review for Beard Papa, I will say this:  they are less sweet than KK's donuts, thus enabling me to devour two to the one donut.  That effectively lifts the caloric intake to 460 against the 200 from the donut.  

........

I just saw that last line in actual writing.  I need to be in denial again...
author: Liz C.

description:
One Word, Legit.

Thanks to our intern who we sent down to get them. You're the man LEE.

I liked the vanilla better than the chocolate.  That's my opinion.  I have heard good things about the Strawberry though.
author: Adam L.

description:
Beard Papa experiential review poem:

So light, the puffs
of Papa's Beard hide
delicious cream  
inside a pastry cave

Very very yummy.  New we need one in Mountain View!
author: Matthew S.

description:
Wow! These must be the best cream puffs in the world. We waited in line for over an hour when they first opened the store, and it was well worth it. The puff is cooked to perfection, and the cream filling has a great flavor and consistency.
I was however disappointed with the chocolate cake. Stick with the cream puffs, its what they do best.
author: Mathew J.

description:
A friend of mine so thoughtfully brought me one of these wonderful treats. I was stuffed from a big lunch and brought it home and placed it into the refrigerator. I took what I thought was going to be one bite that night....well you know the rest...
Crispy little suckers that don't get filled until you order. Get the choclate and wear on your face like a badge of honor.
author: Arlene C.

description:
WARNING: When anxiously eyeing the cream puff, do not breathe too heavily.  Powder will explode onto shirt.

These cream puffs are a delight.  They're not my favorite piece of pastry, but they are good.  I like the vanilla bean ones.  These aren't your usual cream puffs either.  For a half dozen ($12), I thought I would get bite sized pieces.  Imagine my delight when i saw that these things are bigger than my fists.  And I have very big fists.  Next, they are less sweeter than the usual cream puffs.  Which is a good thing.  These things can and will get messy though.
author: Sara D.

description: Cream puffs and chocolate fondant are amazing! Just enough sweetness in each bite. What a gem in San Francisco! Well be back for more.
author: Brittany L.

description:
mmmmMMmMm.. Cream puffs.. mm.. chocolate..

I love these little things.. especially the (you guessed it right) chocolate ones.. Not too sweet, flaky, and warm. I always have to remind myself to just buy a couple of these cream puffs but I always somehow end up with a half of dozen..? That's where I lose connection between my brain and my mouth. These little cream puffs are so powerful...

I always have the urge to ask the workers there if they can let me go behind the counter and let me pump the cream stuff directly in my mouth!! But I can't bare to endure the rejection if they said No, so in a form of a pastry is fine..

I tried the Strawberry and Vanilla ones too.. they're good but how can you compare anything to Chocolate?!? 

Sloppy hugs and Kisses 
H to the W
author: H To The W.

description: It still baffles me to see people lining up out da door for this place. They get high scores on the intoxicating scent of freshly baked puffs and vanilla but the dream pretty much stops there. You are first rudely woken up by the price of each cream puff and then expecting cream puff heaven when you bite into it, you are greeted by sponginess and mediocrity!!
author: Henry W.

description: Good, but it's too big! Aren't cream puffs suppose to be petite? I'd rather have a bunch of small ones than one large one.
author: Leslie P.

description:
The first time I tried Beard Papa's was when I was in Vancouver. What can I say? There is nothing like this place in Toronto. I'll go out of my way to get a cream puff from Beard Papa's. Stopped by this location when I was in San Francisco. It was smaller than the one in Vancouver, but a lot less crowded in the early morning which is a plus in my books. 

This location also had cream puff's that I hadn't seen when I was in Vancouver. There was one filled with pumpkin! :D  I'll be back again in a heart beat when visiting the west coast.  Delicious! You should try this place at least once if you're in the area.
author: Arlene K.

description:
They're like the cream puffs my mom made when I was a kid (except she only made vanilla)!  They offer vanilla, chocolate, & rotate a flavor...it was green tea when I was there.  They're filled/injected with the cream after you order them, so they're fresh & not soggy.  Luckily, when I got there, the line wasn't too long, but while we were sitting outside enjoying our cream puffs, the line grew to twice the length it was when I got there!  They need to open one in the South Bay/Silicon Valley.

This place is basically across the street (Mission) from the Metreon.
author: Linda T.

description:
You have to find the time when it's NOT busy to go.. otherwise, expect 30-40 mins for your $2 cream puffs... 

You have to eat it within an hour after they inject the puffs with the creme, otherwise the contrast of crunchyness and creme gets screwed up...

Each week there is a special flavor, like this weeks is Caramel... I'm still waiting for the green tea flavor, but seem to never catch it when I do get that chance..

Just make sure you kick down a dozen of them ans share em with your friends ;)
author: Wilson L.

description:
I think they should rename this puff pastry shoppe- Puffy McDaddyO- cuz its all that and a big bag of a dozen to go!!!  I guess the Big Papa Beard would be so pleased ...  I have once again rediscovered I still have my sweet tooth :-)
Well I had 2 of the vanilla and 2 of the chocolates and 2 of the cream cheese pie sticks and a chocolate fondant to go...  My oh my  this is something more than getting excited about- cuz its just that orgasmically good- my favorite was the chocolate- the creamy texture unlike a yogurt or mousse consistency- its rich, velvety- like a milkshake spun to a sheer smoothness- thats what i can imagine it to be...each one is hand made, dusted with sugar powder and package in those adorable yellow boxes...I would be prepared to come here over and over again!!!  ;-)~
author: Arissa C.

description:
My friends and coworkers have been going on about these things recently and it was beginning to irritate me.

But someone brought a box of them into the office a few days ago, and I finally tried one. Oh my. This is GOOD.

They're messy though, but that's part of the experience.
author: matthew r.

description:
I'll add to the cacaphony with a small tale.

My friend Shawnee and I decided to drop in one day after lunch, we were there, so what the heck, let's pick up 6! One for me, one for him, 4 for our cubicle pals. 

Bag in hand, we decided to stop and eat ours in the park at Yerba Buena, it was a lovely day, and it made sense to pause and enjoy. I ate mine, and so did Shawnee, then he didn't stop. In an explosion of powdered sugar, 2 more went straight into his pie-hole...whole! In three bites, our supply was decimated...and he was sitting there with powdered sugar all over his face and shirt. Only one lone cream puff made it back to the office, where one lucky friend happily gobbled it up.

Moral to the story: bring a lock-box if you expect to bring these to a party.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
I can't believe I'm giving a cream puff shop a 5 star rating, but I am.  I've always loved the cream puff, and have been disappointed by a few over the years.  It's an easy pastry to make at home, and they freeze really well, so once you make a few dozen you can have them on demand right out of your own freezer.  However, after having the vanilla cream puff at Beard Papa, I have since retired from cream puff making.  

Yes, the Beard Papa cream puff beats mine, hands down.  It's ambrosia, really...always fresh, perfectly creamylicious filling, and light, poofy pastry, sprinkled with just the right amount of powdered sugar. It's a little ball of cream puff heaven.  

I don't feel the same way about the chocolate cream puff as I do the vanilla, but I'm not a chocoholic, either.  If they have other flavors I haven't noticed them...I'm too fixated on the vanilla one.  I see nothing else.  I suggest you get one to go, then leave quickly before you finish eating it.  Otherwise, you might go back in to get a dozen or more to take home.  

Beard Papa actually makes me glad that I live in Berkeley....a safe distance, and BART ride, away from their euphoric creamy deliciousness.
author: s r.

description: Vanilla Cream Puffs!!! Not too sweet, perfect creamy texture, slightly crispy, light, airy outer shell. Simply the best! I wish I could eat these every day . . .
author: Linda C.

description:
YUM! this place is delicious. almost as good as the ones you get in Japan or Taiwain. My personal favorite is the simple plain vanilla one. not overly sweet, perfect amount of filling.
The chocolate one is pretty good as well.

I've had Beard Papa's in Beijing, SF, and Taipei. Taipei had the most unique flavors. SF was the most expensive, unfortunately =(

If you havent tried it, I would definately go and try this out. 

4.5 - only b/c i have had better.
author: cat k.

description:
For those who gave Beard Papa's a low score, they went on a bad day, and did not fully enjoy these savory, heavenly cream puffs.  I have tried all the flavors: Green tea (the best ever), chocolate, strawberry, vanilla, pumpkin, milk tea, and caramel.  The vanilla and chocolate flavors are always there, but the other special flavors are weekly specials.  When the week of the green tea puffs came out, I went about three times, and bought more to take home.  Seriously, these creme puffs are fresh, creamy, and each flavor is so delectable.  Each time I bite down, the cream would slowly drip because it is so soft and fresh~~~

Also, try the chocolate fondant too...and tell them to warm it up first :)

Prices: Ranges from $1.75 to $2.10
author: Emily P.

description:
I resisted Beard Papa for a long time but have finally succumbed to its temptation.  Why?  We were a little hungry and it was too lunch for lunch, too early for Happy Hour...you know, just one of those odd hours of the day.  Then we came upon Beard Papa and it was just calling our names.  We stopped, hesitated, looked at each other and finally braved ourselves to face the demons ahead.  We looked and debated, was still debating when we got to the register...we finally ordered one puff with the flavor of the day, pumpkin.  Yes, just regular puff and not the cookie crust one and no cheesecake stick, nothing.  

We watched as the guy behind picks up a puff and filled it with the goodness we were about to taste but not before he sprinkled some powdered sugar on top.  My first bite...ooohhh...hmmmm...by now my husband is looking and wondering if he'll ever get a bite.  The pumpkin filling was delicious!  It was not sweet, very flavorful and with just the right hint of cinnamon and nutmeg...so soft, smooth and airy.  I did share and hubby agrees with me completely.  I kept asking if they sell the filling by the bottle like whipped cream and wish that they did...
author: Gloria H.

description:
After driving by this store which had moderate to long lines everyday after 5pm and reading so many positive reviews....I gave in to the hype and just HAD to try it.  I'm not much a cream puff guy (just casual) but I love those frozen ones you get in the bucket at Costco.

So I bought a dozen $1.75 Cream Puffs for myself and others (only had Vanilla and Choco at the time) and hoped it would live up to the hype.

Unfortunately they weren't worth it.  I'd say they were worth abt $1 but not 75 cents more than that.  DEFINITELY not worth 1hr wait.....hell....not even 1/2 hr.  Maybe 15 minutes.  So go try it if you have to but be aware that these review people with 5 stars either have plenty of money to burn or just absolutely LIVE for cream puffs.

As for me, I'm heading off to Costco to get me a bucket next time.

One positive by-product of going there tho:  HOT CHICKS!!!  You'll know what I mean when you go there.  WOOT WOOT!!!
author: Gilbert C.

description:
"Wha-What is this? Cream puffs? 'lemme see here..."
-poke, cream spits out-
"Ah! ah, Now that's great.. It's breaking apart already!"
-quickly takes a bite, a-and lick the cream that fell on my hand..-
"-nom nom- Mmm! Now that IS great!"
-takes another quick bite-
"Ok, stomach, get ready for another!"

and thus, I had several bundles of delicious cream-puffiness-goodness..

And made me feel horrible at what I've done later on..

But the instant gratification I had when I was eating them!

Nymo's 100% Approval!


Tip: Watch out for the rather scary, wait, scratch that, VERY scary Papa Beard costume character that sometimes found outside next to the cross-walk trying to get some people in to these delish-cream puffs..
i mean, The friggin' thing BLINKS! BLINKS!
author: Nicolo T.

description:
My first encounter with Beard Papa was someone using it as an icon online and my second was in a subway terminal in China - both places where the delicious flavor of these creme puffs is largely unavailable to me on a day to day basis. However, I have discovered the Jolly Yellow Man mere blocks from my office, which means one thing: Boy, am I in trouble. 

For $2.25 you can have one, in a variety of flavors, assembled fresh before your eyes. I couldn't even bear to acknowledge that you can get more than 1 at a time because there's no way I should really have one let alone many, but I assume there is some sort of price break. They are delicious and quick eating and if health and well-being weren't an issue it's the sort of treat I might have every day.
author: Ian M.

description:
"After taking two bites of the vanilla cream puff, I began looking for a trash can"

"Sorry, I don't mean to rain on this parade of puff puff pass pastry love, but, these creams puffs aren't all that."

"Definitely overrated and not worth the wait"

These are all previous Yelp reviews...do not be swayed fellow yelpers.  Those reviews are from haters and heretics from some east coast village, who have made The City their home.  We, the natives of The City, know not believe such heathen tongue.

Beard Papa's Cream Puffs are divine and make great after dinner snacks.  I would suggest they be served with "Twins Blend" coffee from Cafe Roma after sex or heated political discussion.
author: Buddy R.

description:
I bring all my tourist friends here. I tell them we are getting a cream puff, and they say "I don't like those!"

Then they taste a REAL cream puff, made minutes before entering their mouths, and they SHUT THE HELL UP and let me guide them around without whining.
author: Darren M.

description:
Why are these so good?  
The dude injecting my delicious puff didn't seem to be too thrilled.  Although he lacked excitement I knew his indifferent facial expression really meant that he was filling every tiny bit of my cream puff with LOVE.  Oh man was I right.  

The excitement alone of what flavor will be featured is enough for me to go and eat a puff....
author: Rachel P.

description:
I think the lines have cooled down a little bit since it first opened so it's not as frustrating but I'm still surprised by the number of people who will wait in line forever to get a cream puff or will buy huge boxes full and cart them around as though they've purchased the best dessert ever.

But I should be honest: I waited in line a couple times myself when it first opened. My excuse was that I was downtown already but I admit it, those little suckers are tasty. Chocolate's my favorite but I've had the pumpkin, strawberry, and vanilla and enjoyed those flavors as well. 

So it's a good treat if you're down there but it's not exactly the holy grail of dessert shops. It's definitely a little overrated.
author: Rachael E.

description: Pretty good for the cream puffs but not an over the type of fancy bakery. The least amount for an item ie a cream puff is around $2. Definitely worth a try but not something to be obsessed over. Its conveniently near teh heart of Downtown SF, the Metreon, Yerba Buena, and the CJM. Outtdoor seating is cool on a hot day and the view is pretty.
author: R C.

description: I thought it was just average. Cream puffs are extremely popular in Japan, I've eaten so many different puffs better than that. I hope they'll catch up soon, making more creative puffs, like chestnut puffs or at least green tea puffs. Now there is a new one in Blooming dale on Market.
author: Yoko S.

description: So delicious! My fav is the eclair with vanilla. Stick to the original vanilla cream puff.. The strawberry and Choco cream were just ok :)! Must eat within the first 24 hours so only buy what u can eat!
author: Sunny C.

description:
If I farted in here, I don't think anyone would have noticed.  The vanilla aroma is just so thick that's all that you could smell.

Cream puff was good, but kinda wasn't memorable.
author: Chris T.

description: Me and my wife just ordered the basic cream puffs with vanilla filling and I'm glad we did, they are great. The puffs are a good size and they're not skimpy on the filling, great flavor all the way through. Great snack or dessert while shopping at Union Square. We are definitely going back for seconds :-)
author: Alex M.

description:
Speaking as a soft, doughy cream-filled human who enjoys baking soft, doughy cream-filled creampuffs, I was underwhelmed by beard papa.  Yeah, they are a hell of a lot better than the motor oil aftertaste of a Krispy Kreme, and the shells taste fresh and natural, but nowhere as good as homemade (which are not actually all that hard to make).  

I tried two of the custard filled ones, which were more of a custard explosion with a hint o creampuff.  Next time I'll have to try the eclairs to test out the taste of the creampuffs alone.  Well, that's what I'm telling myself the next dozen is for, anyways...
author: Dave S.

description:
I haven't been here yet-- BUT...
I have made cream puffs at home and they were FANTASTIC. And surprisingly NOT difficult to make or easy to mess up.  Going off of what most people have said, what's the big deal? Someone let me know.  I mean, Costco has a box of frozen ones that are dang tasty too.  
Seriously, let me know. Make me a believer. I heart pastries!
author: Robyn E.

description:
I walked by this new Beard papa's location while on my way to the Linux World Expo last week, so very tempted and went inside to get my fill of the giant cream puffs. 

- equally excellent Beard Papa as down here in the south bay. 

- they had an excellent special of the week for "pumpkin", a bit early for Oct, but I luv Pumpkin flavoured stuff.. 

- pricing is 10% more expensive than down here, it's $1.95 vs. $2.15 up in SF.
author: Winifred X.

description:
I have had the fortune to try these in SF and Boston.  The SF ones were delivered to me by a friend, so didn't have to face the lines and the walk from the parking structure.  The vanilla bean is excellent, all I want to do is eat the vanilla pudding, light and flavorful. the puff wasn't soggy.  The chocolate cream was good but not as good at the vanilla.

In Boston, at Faneuil Hall, they have a shop with many more items to choose from, tried the chocolate lava cake, underwhelmed and not the flowing chocolate lava like expected but the strawberry cream was excellent, I would say even better then the vanilla bean and I love the vanilla bean.  They also had a vanilla bean puff with blueberry preserves, which was yummy.

Can hardly wait for new flavors at the SF store.  One coming to the South Bay in Redwood City in August 2006...yippee!
author: Deb N.

description:
Someone once said their favorite food in this world was bearded clams... 

Speaking of beards, if you can't get enough of the above, you'll certainly find these cream puffs an adequate substitute.  Light, creamy, not too sweet, and very erotic.

Flavors include chocolate, vanilla, green tea, camel-toe, split beaver...
author: Gracie-C Y.

description:
Yum yum yum. The puff part always smells sooooo good. Even hours after buying them. And the cream filling is light and creamy, almost like a yogurt consistency. 

Had the vanilla (my fav so far between chocolate and vanilla), my sister had caramel (this week's flavor of the week) and she loved it. 

We both tried to go back (separately) to get some more. Did I mention, yum?

I can never remember on what side of the Metreon this place is at.
author: B B.

description: When I first had Beard Papa's I was blown away. Who would have thought these little desert treats would be such a delicacy? I had to ask where this Beard Papa's was located when a parent at my work brought some for the employees. I've since been here a few times to grab some cream puffs. They have weekly flavors - green tea is a must.
author: Edgar G.

description:
Let me just say ....

Caramel Cream Puff, sprinkled with cinnamon sugar - tastes like french toast in a cream puff. Unless you hate french toast and delicious things, try it.
author: kristen b.

description:
TASTY TASTY TASTY....

But I still don't get the lines... I mean come on now ... get there early like before they open and be 1st in line.
author: Teddy d.

description:
It's all about the puff here.  No trappings, no nothing.  I mean, it's clean, nothing really wrong, but go in, order, and walk away before you try and buy more.  

These are lovely. I've always enjoyed a good cream puff, not the Chinese weird overly fatty, super sweet, no soul puffs.  I love a Japanese cream puff.  Now note:  for those not of the Asian persuasion, this probably seems weird. I mean, aren't your people lactose intollerant?  Maybe, but we love the French baking, and some things we have elevated to a new level.  White bread for toast, and cream puffs are two of them.  The French have nothing on these.

I got to have a vanilla bean (my favorite thus far), chocolate, and caramel puff.  The chocolate is good, but I'm not a chocolate person.  A touch pudding-like in the middle even.  The caramel was sweet, rich, and buttery in flavor.  The vanilla bean was very vanilla, light, sweet, but not cloyingly so, and just lovely.  The pastry itself was perfectly cooked, and they make them to order in front of you. How cool is that?  They never sit and get soggy.

That's the mark of a good puff, and I'll do it again.  I think the green tea is definitely on the list to try sooner than later.
author: Erin O.

description:
This is my third review of places from my past weekend of non-stop eating!  I only gained another ten pounds, give or take.

Still on my "Day in SF" with my girlfriends...
We had planned to stop for drinks and dessert at Cheesecake Factory but decided we were too full.  On our way towards the SF Shopping Centre, we made a detour and hit up Beard Papa's.  It smells so good when you walk through the door.  

My friend ordered a 6-pack and OMG, I was in love.  The cream puff was so freakin' yummy.  It was the perfect dessert after our huge lunch.  

There were four of us who went which means there were 2 cream puffs left over.  I resisted the urge to accept the last two to take home since I had already grabbed the last prawn at lunch.:P  

Will definitely visit one of the Bay Area locations soon and stock up.
author: Flory T.

description:
Dear Beard Papa's,

Why is it that every time you and I meet and I give your cream puff love bites, that your yummy massive thick creamy custard squirts everywhere?

Can't you control yourself. 

HAHA. I'm so bad.
Seriously though, the cream puffs are very good. You just need one for complete satisfaction.
author: Charlene C.

description:
Even if I was fucked up on Tina and lost all my teeth, I would still find a way to get my cream puff on!   Hell, I'd trick myself out right now for one--no make that two.

My only complaint is they aren't open early enough in the morning for me to get my "fix" before work.
author: Paul D.

description:
The vanilla cream puffs will enter the hall of pastry fame.  If you try just one of the puffs, vanilla is the port of entry for you.  Few establishments can make divinity out of vanilla, but this bakery has done it.

The chocolate cream puffs, however, look as though someone dumped an ashtray on top of them, and the cocoa is hardly at par with lowly brands such as Hersheys.   The chocolate eclairs should be removed from the menu as well.  

Beard Papa also offers weekly specials, and it is important to do your own taste test once per week.  The special green tea cream puffs sent me on a culinary high which lasted a few hours!   I must now wait another five weeks or so for their return.   :D
author: Daniel C.

description:
I think some over-hyped expectations, planted in my brain by Beard Papa's little minions, caused my virginal puff experience to be somewhat deflated.  I did like the fact that I could see little vanilla beans in my vanilla cream (at least I'm hoping they were vanilla beans, and NOT the 0.00002% feces allowed by the FDA)

Overall, pretty tasty, but not worth the wait.  I definitely enjoyed my first bite of a Krispy Kreme a lot more . . .
author: Jeffrey H.

description:
After hearing about this place so much, I decided to go ahead and give it a try. Luckily, when I got there, there was no line. I wanted to try the milk tea flavor but since it was not the weekly special, I went for the original vanilla custard. I was debating to myself whether or not I should just get one or buy 6 and take them home. And then, the little voice in my head told me that if i bought the 6, i probably would've just eaten it all by myself and would've regretted it for the day. More like I would've had to force myself on the treadmill for 2 hours to burn all those unwanted calories off. So I just got one.

I have to say, it wasn't anything special. It was good and the pastry was crunchy and it was airy and gooey inside. It took me less than 2 minutes to eat the whole thing. It's like the krispy kreme of cream puffs. Small and not so filling, but good enough to have more. But I'd rather have a more filling cream puff so I wouldn't want to eat any more. I sat out in front and then as I was about to leave a line started forming. I'm glad I got there when I did.  Of course, since it was a windy day I had to take a look in the mirror to make sure I didn't have any gooey gunk on my face. 
The guy that helped me told me that they were going to have the green tea flavor next week.  So FYI to anyone that's reading this review right now! (8/23/06)
author: Pippi L.

description:
Freshly made cream puffs - yum! Need I say more?

Simple and delicate yummy cream puffs. My favorite is the green tea and vanilla. The pumpkin is wonderful in the fall too. I have not ventured into their other treats though since the cream puffs are so yummy. Not too sweet but very satisfying.
author: Glenn G.

description: Bella purchases a few vanilla bean cream puffs.  I'm not a huge cream puff fan but for a chain they make a fantastic cream puff.  You can see the specks of vanilla bean throughout the tasty custard.
author: David E.

description:
Uh, yeah, these are heaven.  For real.

My co-worker and I got a Daily Candy email one day that notified us to the cream puff bakery just two blocks (dangerous) from our place of employment.  Before lunch, we headed over and ordered the vanilla cream puff (other flavors are not currently available).  We waited a few minutes as a fresh batch of puffs came out of the oven and watched in amazement as the baker inserted the vanilla cream into the pastry.  A woman then gave the puffs a dusting of powdered sugar and handed the treats to us.

As we sat down on a sunny bench right outside, we looked at each other and exclaimed our excitement.  We both admitted, however, that we thought we didn't like cream puffs or couldn't remember having or wanting one before.  Even with this prejudice, the anticipation from the Daily Candy blurb and all of the happy customers in the surrounding area made us eager to stuff our faces.  Which we did.

Oh, that first bite!  The warm buttery outer layers of pastry hit my tongue and were immediately followed by the cold cream custard filling.  We exclaimed many superlatives as we ate the puffs in a 2 minute span that felt like time had stopped.  "Look, I can see pieces of vanilla bean!" my co-worker stated with glee.  "It's like a vanilla cloud in my mouth!" I replied.

We walked back to the office unable to gripe about the day's awful start and instead talked about the greatness of the puff.  The hope and excitement for two weeks to pass until we could come back when they introduce chocolate.  Oh yes, it made our day.  Thank you, papa beard.  Thank you.
author: Sarah L.

description:
At first, when this shop opened and there was all this crazy hype, I was like, "what's the big deal?  It's JUST a cream puff."

Well, yes and no.  On some level--yes, it's just a cream puff.  But the shell is crisper than most cream puffs, and although I like my fillings with a touch more custard, this is still pretty good.

The cream puffs are $1.75 good, but not wait-in-line-for-an-hour good.

I might bump it up a star once I try the more novel flavors... say, green tea?
author: Desdemona C.

description:
It's a cream puff, folks. 

Whooptie doo!
author: Cliff C.

description:
I sure would be curious to read the other reviews where the creampuffs are likened with great sex. 

I can attest that after experiencing the pumpkin, green tea, strawberries and chocolate flavors, one can literally just "die and go to heaven".
author: Miles G.

description: MMM how can you go wrong with Cream in Carbs?? I bought a Townhog coupon for 1 dozen of the chocolate cream puffs. I called to ask them can I mix other puffs and they said no.
