*A word of caution to those who get them to go... you will get home and open your box to a soggy bottomed puff... forget buying in high numbers.  Go often and eat them fresh.  They are a little drop of joy!*
author: Alicia W.

description:
I can't give this place five stars not because it's not LIKE other cream puffs you have eaten before. 

I simply think this location can do better than what they are doing now.

I literally waited 6 months for them to open at this location. Tried a couple times, and yes it was true that this place used to give fresh, big, cream stuffed puffs. My favorite is always vanilla for sure, but have also tried and liked Milk tea, pumkin and strawberry. Next one down my list is going to be green tea. 

This place is good as a cafe, and to hang out for a lil bit. For better/ fresher puffs, try the one in Westfield Center.
author: David C.

description:
Sure there is a lot of hype behind this place, but they sure do back it up.

The decor inside the place can be best described as fun/kiddy as it is pretty bright and colorful. 

The puffs are definitely the star of the show here. While they have other items on the menu (eclairs, cheese cake, etc..) they simply cannot compare to the cream puffs. 

The filling has a light creamy texture and the pastry shell is fluffy and flaky.  My favorite used to be vanilla but that pushed to second when I tasted the strawberry which has strawberry bits in the filling. Chocolate is a distant third, and the others I'm just not as fond of. 

I like to break mine apart and eat them that way, rather than trying to bite into the whole puff as it can get messy. Either way, Beard Papa is a guilty pleasure that I'm more than willing to indulge in when I get a craving. They just opened another location in Redwood City 3 minutes from where I work, so I can get my fix after work without having to pay for parking in SF.
author: Alson L.

description:
Yummm. Beard Papas remind me of homeee. That, and I love custard. Yumm.

Before these guys came to SF, I could only get my fix at Hollywood Highland in LA... there is however something a little different from the ones in Asia... its like 3/4 the size of the ones I am used to... But its ok. I can live with that. =)
author: Gobbledygook C.

description: I came to pickup dessert for the hubby and I and the vanilla cream puff and vanilla eclair were great!  Definitely worth the fat and calories...so delectable.  ;-)
author: Lizete S.

description:
One word: YUUUMMMMMMMMMAAAYYYYYY!

I'm intrigued by these perfect cream puffs.  They aren't overly sweet on the inside [it's JUST right] and are perfectly crispy on the outside.   My sister always brings some home to share with us and I always feel so guilty after eating them.  [ lotsa carbs :T ]

All in all, these cream puffs are worth trying out (if you haven't already).  It's probably as close to food nirvana as you can get!
author: Natalie P.

description: The puff itself is good. It's filled with way too much cream for my taste. And they are large and come with a larger price tag. It's hard to even take a bite without getting cream ALL over your face.  What's disappointing is their flavored cream puffs. Example, the Green Tea cream puff. I would think the cream is flavored with green tea or the puff baked with a green tea flavoring, NO. All they do is sprinkle green tea powder over the cream puff.    The only great thing is that their cream puffs are not way too sweet like the normal cream puffs sold in donut shops.
author: Ms. T.

description: Yum...I love their Vanilla Cream Puffs.
author: Helen V.

description:
The first time we got Cream Puffs, we were disappointed as the vanilla and chocolate were both just mediocre.

I am happy to say that the flavors are much better now, the caramel is lovely and the service is always very nice.
author: Luna R.

description: Mmmm. My sweet tooth thanks the sugar fairy for bringing me to SF and Beard Papa. Tried the vanilla and chocolate flavors - the custard was smooth with just the right hint of flavor. The pastry was suitably crusty on the outside and the inside airy. I thought it was perfect.
author: Lyn P.

description:
I've been torn about whether or not to write this review the past week and my conscience got to me because before this visit - I would only have positive things to say about them. I've always been a fan of theirs even before their stores in the States.  

Anyways so here goes: After a long day my friends and I stopped by to get some sweets before heading home.  I was just going to get my standard chocolate creme puffs since their green tea was not their flavor this week.  (Sad, I know...they should have green tea as their regular flavor!!!)  But before I ordered I saw they were promoting a new product - mango madness.  By the look of the ad it looked good, I asked the lady at the register what was in it - she said the following "mangoes, shaved ice, mango mousse and sweetening syrup.  I'm was thinking alright why not - so yea...not what I had expected at all.  It was mostly filled with more ice than mangoes & no where did i see any mango mousse.  Needless to say I was more than disappointed so anyway I moved on to my go-to creme puff.  Except this tasted differently than normal and not in a good way.  All and all, their quality seemed to have decreased since they have first opened which is disappointing but I guess this way, I can still fit into my jeans.
author: Vivian W.

description: I could eat them everyday, but would most likely die of a heart attack. They taste great, but are not physically filling so, you have chance of overeating.
author: Nathan M.

description: This is the SECOND time I've been disappointed by the taste of white gooey stuff.  Like before, it wasn't what I had thought it would be.  It left me messy and sticky. It wasn't too horrible that I couldn't swallow it though.  Nonetheless, I will only go there again if it's with someone I love and they REALLY want me to.
author: Jay H.

description: The combination of cream and puff is unbelievable- friends laugh when I tell them but soon after their first bite they completely agree. To top off the delicious forbidden treats (I sometimes take a 3 block detour to not pass by) I love the instant smell of butter as soon as you walk into the shop.. heaven.
author: Seema M.

description: I dont know that I've ever dreamed of a chocolate-filled sugar cookie cream puff, but I might now. It's a pretty light alternative to other chocolate-filled things, but still satisfies the craving. The cheesecake sticks here, on the other hand, were tasteless, and not in the fun/risqué way of the establishments near Broadway and Columbus ... I'm talking about that bookstore, of course. Maybe reviewing this place partially based on something they aren't really known for is unfair, but, hey, don't offer a man portable cheesecake unless you know it's good.
author: Art Q.

description:
New here to yelp and still thinking of something witty for my profile. "

First of all just want to say...yes I am addicted to Beard Papa Cream Puffs hehe.  I've enjoyed BP in Japan, Singapore, Hollywood, Gardena, and now here in the Bay Area.  My opinion is purely my opinion and everyone is entitled to their own.  I'm just here to educate and answer questions raised on previous reviews.

FYI...this is a long post and yes I have too much time on my hands =).  I base all my info on a 15min chat session with the manager of the Yerba Buena store and my personal experiences.

1) Japanese vs French Puffs
Keep in mind this is a Japanese style cream puff.  Hence the crispy shell, softer dough inside, and semi-sweet japanese Nama custard (custard and whipped cream).  I believe this is what makes the taste and texture unique.  French style puffs are softer and have a heavier, sweeter cream.  See #2 below for puff size differences.

2) Napkins required?
First of all, these puffs are big and a good amount of japanese style custard cream is purposely injected into the crispy shells.  Thus the flaky shell, amt of cream, and dusted baker's sugar leads to quite a mess.  If you saw the CNN Anderson Cooper piece on BP, the messy eating experience was one of the funny things they mentioned.  **WARNING...my opinion here** I personally feel you get quality and quantity in this pastry.  Because of the larger size puff and extra room for cream, I feel like I'm getting my money's worth and don't experience the sugar sickness afterwards because of the lighter, semi-sweet custard.  I couldn't consume french style cream in equal amounts...hmm now that I think of it maybe that's why French cream puffs are smaller. 

3) Pricey?
Some may think $1.75 for a cream puff is expensive, but personally for me and my taste...I'd rather pay for a fresh, larger-than-norm BP puff than $3 for a Satura Cream Puff (decent, but not flaky...more bread like), $1.50 for a Ranch 99 Cream Puff, or $2+ for a behind-the-glass muffin/scone/danish at my local Starbucks.  But a BP puff does go perfectly with Starbuck's dark roast.

4) Are they really fresh?
Shells are baked every 20mins and custard made every 2-3hours.  The puffs are never served hot or piping from the oven.  They need to be cooled out of the oven to get that flaky texture.  If the shells are not cooled properly or if the custard is pumped in too soon...moisture will soften the shells prematurely.  

5) Why the lines?
Going back to #4 above, the lines primarily form when patrons are left waiting for the ovens to finish baking or when the puff are still in the cooling process.  Plus add in the marketing factor here.

6) What's up with all the workers?
Every BP I've visited has had a Cream Puff line of workers so its part of the experience whether you like it or not.  Keep in mind, if they had fewer workers things might move slower.  But there is a difference between BP bakeries ambiance...I'll explain.  Have your ever been to a sushi restaurant where they greet you loudly in Japanese, proceed to shout orders, bow to you while saying Domo (sp?).  Well some BP's have this same experience where they greet/shout in Japanese which makes it more "entertaining"...purely my opinion here.  The Yerba Buena store is bland in this sense, but at least the workers are nice and courteous.    

7) Other locations?
There are two more to be open this year...Redwood City and the SF Center a block away.  Is it just me or are the two SF stores a bit close?  Why not spread them out?  In any case, living in the Peninsula myself...I'll be a regular in the Redwood City spot.  After doing a bit of research with the Yerba Buena baker, the Redwood City BP will be bigger, have more coffee house style seating, and have a barista.

8) Why only vanilla?  Where's the fondant and cheesecake fingers?
The manager I spoke to didn't really have a good answer here, but at least they finally started serving chocolate puffs this week.  As for the fondant and cheesecake fingers...good news is that  they also are baked fresh daily, bad news is that they don't start selling these sweets until a month after grand opening...bah! 

9) Who is Beard Papa?
Well its kind of an entertaining story...I suggest you walk in and ask one of the workers.

Sorry for the Beard Papa thesis, hopefully you'll enjoy them as much as I do!
author: Alexa M.

description: Sorry, I don't mean to rain on this parade of puff puff pass pastry love, but, these creams puffs aren't all that. I've had both the vanilla and green tea flavors and I found both were equally bland.
author: Neil K.

description: I'm going to open a little store called Pube Mama's Cream Shoppe. Then I will have millions of people stalk my mediocre pastries and hunt down my employees. They will line the streets, throw caution to the wind and block every nearby bus stop, push the handicapped and elderly out of the way, clothesline small children, and lie to friends about where they've been. They will sell unborn babies, dig through neighbor's couch cushions, and panhandle the 'loin to score $12 for a mother fucking 6 pack of creamy creams. Then I will retire a rich, fat, and happy. Done.
author: Katelin H.

description:
tasty tasty.  a great munchie to sneak into the metreon to be the envy of other moviegoers!

the dough for the puffs is shipped daily from japan.  there are 3 layers, the top and bottom which turn into the crispier crust, and the middle inside layer, which becomes light and fluffy.  there are chocolate and vanilla creams, then 5 other flavors which are rotated weekly (caramel, green tea, milk tea, pumpkin and strawberry).  they are kinda messy but a great snack.  mmmmm.  i wish you could get the puffs hot and fresh but i guess it jacks up the cream.  ah well.

FYI - each puff is 220 calories.
author: Junglist S.

description: After finishing an eclair and a cup of coffee I was shocked to find one container marked trash. I was served an eclair in a paper sleeve on a paper plate with paper napkins and a cup of coffee in a paper cup with a paper heat shield all of which are compostable. Apparently it is Beard Papas policy to make zero effort to be environmentally friendly and sent all of this to the landfill. Shame on you Beard Papa I will not return. boooooooooo!!
author: dan c.

description: i think the papa got too "happy" and went cream crazy.......a cream puff should have a good balance of crust to cream.....is it just me or are these the biggest mutant cream puffs you have ever seen?....it's oooozing cream after the first bite....i think i need a bib....bit too sweet for my tastes....but, the crust is crispy and just right......
author: Hen A.

description: So, apparently I'm the 120th person to review Beard Papa. No surprise there, because that's about how many people we had to wait in line behind. So obviously this review is totally unnecessary. So I'll just conclude by saying: what the hell is the fuss about? It's pastry, people. And not very exciting pastry at that. Also, the strange little old white gnome man freaks me out. Is this some sort of Japanese pop culture icon? It's wierd.
author: Megan W.

description: Ahhh I love this place!! I wish I knew where there was one in LA... This location is basically just a tiny little shop window that can get pretty crowded, especially in the morning. They have rotating flavors on different days and sometimes they even have surprise special flavors ;) Obviously the green tea and chocolate are BOMB but I've had the coffee and pumpkin flavors before and they're good too. The surprising thing is that Beard Papa's makes excellent coffee, making it a great place to stop in for breakfast on your way to work. Downside of the outdoor seating area is that it's on the north side of a skyscraper (no sun) but you can walk across the street to Yerba Buena park to relax and enjoy cream-filled puff heaven.
author: Alexander M.

description: Dear God. This is the fifth time my co-worker has schlepped out to bring back three boxes of these goodies. The entire room goes into about 5 minutes of silence (peppered with mmmmmmm's) after multiple discussions regarding flavor selection, splitting issues etc. These cream puffs really are the shit. Today he brought vanilla, chocolate and caramel which was surprisingly not too sweet. The custard filling isn't chalky or even heavy. Just perfect. Vanilla is definitely the best flavor, stick with that and you will not go wrong.
author: margot b.

description: I finally know who's my Daddy, after dining on a delectable cream puff from Bearded Papas. These creamy, rich treats are every bit a sin wrapped in puff pastry. The filling is a rich, thick consistency. This is not your average cream puff- it's stuffed with a pudding-like creme brulee colored creme that's flavored by flecks of vanilla bean. Savor one over a cup of steaming hot coffee. Resist the urge to stuff your face with one and swallow it whole because these cream puffs are worth a try despite their heavy caloric value...aw hell just try them...even if you're on a diet...thank me later.
author: Jessica D.

description: Too much hype.  I hate it when the hype takes over.  This place has good puffs, but I don't like waiting in line for them.  If I wait longer than ten minutes I expect orgasmic puffs.
author: Honey L.

description: I'm not a cream puff aficionado, so they tasted fine to me--a bit expensive, but good, nonetheless.  I especially like their bearded old man logo; I like it better than the cream puffs themselves.  The location is not hard to find on Mission.  It's close to The Metreon.  I look forward to their other flavors (green tea, here I come!).
author: Marsha Z.

description: Why are you even reading this? Go get a chocolate cream puff now. That's all, I can't say anymore.
author: reb f.

description: These cream puffs are average at best, people!!!  why the hell is there always a line out the door and around the corner.  I know that not everyone who keeps this place in business is a tourist, but seriously...  there is nothing to write home about.  The pasty dough is so-so (depending on how close to a fresh batch you are), the filling is not vanilla-y enough, and the service is passable at best.
author: Robert R.

description: I'm only writing this so you can see that this week's special flavor is MILK TEA!!!!!!!  my favorite beverage at 3pm and cream puff flavor. And if you miss it this week, you have to wait for the rotation of about six flavors, so thats 1.5 months. Your welcome.
author: Wakako U.

description: Yuck.  I know I'm a European and all and thus have higher standards for baked goods.  But these are gross.  Bland tasting -- Sort of like IHOP pancakes.  Not at all what a perfect cream puff is supposed to taste like.   I don't get the hype.
author: green t.

description: Oh my lord ! eating a chocolate beard papa cream puff is a bit like heaven ... mmmmmmmmm im now distracted. They are addictive. I want one now. mmmmmmmm!
author: Amy W.

description: I am actually suppose to be doing some school work but instead I am writing a update on Beard Papa's. I wouldn't normally eat cream. But more Bread Papa's I would! The puff is super light which makes you feel like you have just taken a bite of heaven and then the creamy cream comes after you take a bite..what a good combination!
author: Janet Z.

description: Every time I visited SF, I had to go to Bread Papa's.  I love green tea and chocolate cream puffs.  I think it's about 2.50$ and I can eat 3-4 of them at a time LOL.  Mango with ice is also good for a hot hazy day in MOMA.

author: Shanti G.

description:
six puffs and two beers. not a bad hour at work.

now i am ashamed to admit that i quietly consumed such a gluttonous amount of these delicious vanilla speckled creamy and crispy little sweets, but as testament to their scrumptiousness i did not feel ill for a moment and licked my fingers up to the very last one. i am in eager anticipation of the cheese cake sticks and caramel and green tea flavors. 

wicked 'who's your papa?' t-shirts, too. oh and i must agree with johnny about opening at ten am. bad biz move. also the inefficient and wholly unnecessary assembly line: one-to-pay (pass) one-to-pump (pass) one to powder (pass) one to box (pass) one to hold, tape and bag pastry. this prep and serve style is the perfect example of why the unemployment rate in japan has decreased since the late '90's.
author: Ligaya T.

description: If you like Beard Papa's, then they're basically the same wherever you go, but this location is the only I've seen in SF that has the same full menu that I saw at the Hollywood Highland store when I first popped my Beard Papa cherry.
author: Arnold G.

description: My dad and I were wandering around this area (MOMA and what not) and our eyes lit up when we saw best cream puffs sign...we both LOVE cream puffs! so we headed in all excited for what awaited us. We got one vanilla one chocolate cream. Took a bite...and slightly disappointed. The cream was amazing no doubt but the pastry part left to be desired. Maybe because everything was kinda lukewarm which left me feeling blah about the cream puffs. vanilla was definitely better than chocolate and I love chocolate. I'll come back if in the area to try other things but the people working seemed very bored and uninterested but basically it was a tad of a let down.
author: Kaitie D.

description:
This aint' no mom's cream puffs.  My mom uses rum in her recipe.  

The first time I had a Beard Papa's was in LA early last month.  Thanks Donna (a friend's ex-girlfriend). Anyway, I liked it so much I wanted to try the one in SF.

After I picked up my Elite shirt (Thanks Jess T.) I walked over and ordered one vanilla bean.  I took it to my client's work and I should have ordered one for everyone in the office, between me and two other gals - the cream puff was gone in less than a minute.

I subtracted another star because of the lack of street/metered parking around this location.
author: Mona B.

description: The cream puffs are insanely delicious. I'm really glad this place isn't in my neighborhood or I would surely be 5 pounds heavier!
author: jen w.

description:
Was debating whether to give 3 stars or four, but initially settled on four stars. Went there today with boyfriend, which would make it my second time there. There were only  two people ahead of me, so once we placed our orders we had our two cream puffs (one chocolate, one pumpkin)  within seconds. 
My initial reaction to the pumpkin cream puff : "mmmm....tastes like fall, here you have to try some" 
Boyfriend's reaction to the pumkin puff: "yeah you're right tastes just like fall" 
I should say that I in turn had a bite of the chocolate, the chocolate was subtle but it worked. I've read that some people were put off by the runniness of the cream (is that even a word?) well anyway, I liked that the custard wasn't thick. it was like eating a mini eclair, without the chocolate coating.If a simple little pastry inspires a bit of sharing, and a few images of pumpkins, and turkeys, and trick or treating, and things related to fall, then four stars it is.
Hmmm.....minus one star for making me write such a brady bunch ending. yikes!
author: X marks the spot ..

description: I don't get it? It is just a cream puff. It was good, but nothing phenomenal. I heard that it is supposed to be a mix of pate coux and pie dough in order to  make a particular texture to the puff, but I couldn't tell the difference. Not to mention, they didn't have decaf coffee the day I went and I couldn't handle the real stuff that day.
author: Esa Y.

description: Beard Papa's lives up to all the hype.  I finally took a bite in to one today and I can't get the- "Crisp flaky outside, perfectly sweetened vanilla custard, and a touch of  powdered sugar on top" off my mind.  Yeah man that good, although it's very messy.  I must have looked like a kid with all that powdered sugar all over my shirt.  Good thing custard didn't make it's way on my shirt also.  I'm only giving this spot 4 stars right now because vanilla cream puffs are the only thing on the menu that is available.  6 other flavors to follow and 2 other desserts.  I only had to wait 5 minutes and this was during the late afternoon.
author: Jason A.

description: always a little messy and a little disappointing that they don't have the flavor i want.  I think that they rotate flavors daily or weekly or something.  so i usually end up with vanilla or something.  but certainly not bad.  and i like the name.  the dude on the logo reminds me of that one dude from tin tin or something.
author: Jeremy S.

description: Dangerous is how I describe these.  I had both the vanilla and the strawberry ones.  Here's a good way to describe how good they are:  I was eating them while walking down the street and all the crumbs were falling all over me and I didn't care.  Everyone was staring at me, wish I had a camera shot of it.  The parking is difficult in this area though and the traffic can be unbearable around this area on Mission too.  Be warned :)  Oh, and the people that don't like them, are probably the same people that don't like true Japanese food that has very delicate flavors.  The flavor of these is supposed to be very delicate, not like eating Italian or French pastries.  I love this type of delicate flavor..
author: Mitch A.

description: excellent cream puffs made fresh that melt in your mouth!
author: Roshan K.

description:
While in line, some lady in front of us orders 6 dozen cream puffs.  SIX DOZEN!  "Six dozen?  That's 60 cream puffs..", the cashier says.  I think she misses the exclamation.  Tells one of the other workers to get on it.  The worker stares at the customer up and down thinking "Dammnnn wtf, you gonna eat all of that by yourself?"  We patiently wait.  Dammit I only wanted 1..ONE cream puff, they better not make us wait.  Got the cream puff, slowly devoured mine while Christina ravaged and salivated through it like some Pavlovian beast.  She goes on to eat her Vietnamese sandwich from across the street while I am still slowly devouring my cream puff, licking the corners of my mouth.  Twas a sensual experience for moi.  Distressed by my cream puff's long existence, Christina takes out the paper that once wrapped her cream puff, spreads it open and begins to lick each and every inch of leftover cream.  I don't even think a security guard dog can tell that a cream puff was on there.  I had to keep her from eating the paper.  Poor slobbered piece of paper.

They lack a star because they're made cold.  :( I wish they were warm but eh..couldn't wait to get back to Daly City to pop it in the microwave.  It would be gone by then!  Oh!  And Vanilla is the way to go!!
author: Joellene B.

description:
Puff of magic deliciousness......... It was  a Wednesday afternoon and my co-worker and I needed a little afternoon pick me up. I knew exactly what we needed. I can almost feel the rush of sugar flowing to my brain just thinking about it now. We left the office and walked the 6 blocks down Mission St. to Beard Papa's   (across from the Metreon). This is the second time I've been to this location and it still amazes me how the Beard Papa employees turn out these little cream puffs and cakes as fast as one of Willy Wonkas assembly line oompa loompas. I hope that's not un PC to say, woops. 
They have the expected flavors such as strawberry, chocolate, and vanilla. But for the slightly more adventurous they also have Green Tea and Coffee. With the first Beard Papa's locations opening in Japan in 1999, this chain seems to be catching on pretty quickly in the U.S. Us Americans do like us some sugar and fried goodness! And since Krispy Kreme is pretty much non-existent in the SF (except for the stale versions in Safeway), I think Beard Papa's will be a success.  And if you complain about enhaling the powdered sugar then you deserve to be eating a stale doughnut instead.
 
Oh and their slogan is "fresh and natural". How can you go wrong? Okay I believe the fresh part because I witnessed it with my own eyes, but how all of that scrumcious cream can be "natural" is beyond me. All I know is that these little suckers are darn tasty! Highly recommend them to perk up any workday.
author: jenna s.

description: Was in town visiting my sister and some friends and had to go to Beard Papa's.  I had heard incredible stories about these Japanese style creme puffs from two of my friends and figured I'd give them a try.  There was a line going out the door (about a 15-20 minute wait) when I got there.  Figured I'd pick some up for my sister and her husband for letting me crash at their place for the weekend.  Placed an order for a dozen vanilla and chocolate creme puffs and a fondant (it looks like a chocolate cake with chocolate oozing out of the center) but they ran out of the fondant.  So I ended settling for their special creme puff of the week... a caramel puff.... delicious.  I think I may have to go back for some more for the drive back home.
author: Ken L.

description: Mmmm..  there's always room for cream puffs. Beard Papa's managed to make it across the Pacific Ocean from Japan to the US. It is a bit more expensive here than in Japan, although the ingredients should be cheaper here. I liked this location's cream taste better than the one in LA (near the Chinese Theater). I can probably eat 5 cream puffs if calories weren't an issue. :)
author: Orie M.

description: Yummy vanila cream puff... aaaaa...   It makes up for the other points that I lost for the day eating this damn thing.
author: Rachelle Q.

description: If only this place was called Beard Mama so I can legally marry it's Cream Puffed goodness!
author: Harry B.

description: So they've screwed up my order and the wait is sometimes unbearable... I'm still a sucker for their cream puffs.
author: Vitamin C.

description: Had an urge for cream puffs and stopped by here.  I had 2 of these yummy things; vanilla and green tea.  They sure hit the spot and then some!!!  I felt a little bloated afterward.  Perhaps one would've been enough...
author: Jeff H.

description: I love beard papa cream puffs! they are soooo good! All good, nothing bad, enough said.
author: meL Z.

description:
it was a delight receiving a surprise from my boyfriend that sunday afternoon picking him up from downtown one day. "i got a surprise for you". OOOOO excite! trying to take a sneak peak into the plastic bag he held on his lap after getting in my car i saw nothing but a yellow box. what's inside? a hat maybe? maybe a pet turtle? 
no, even better. sugary,flaky cream puffs with a sinful custard on the inside. 

that was 15 pounds ago. if i lose the 15 pounds i gained since then and get my boyfriend back, i'll give you your 2 more stars. (sobbing). but otherwise i'm sitting on my couch with my beard papa's cream puffs and bucket of fried chicken watching a fresh prince of bell air marathon. oh carlton, you can have my heart any time.
author: Renae C.

description: I good amount of time has passed since MacWorld and I still dream of these pastries. A better coffee experience would compliment these treats well. Thanks to Yelp members and their recommendations - this was a highlight of the trip. We found we were actually planning our day around Beard Papa's. How sad is that?
author: Denver D.

description: I'm hopelessly addicted.  I buy them by the 6 pack and I don't share.  I can't believe there are only three locations (two in SF) to get these puffy pastries of pure pleasure.  Papa, come to mama...
author: Madame X.

description: This place deserves a real 5 star rating....the chocolate cream puff is eccelent, and totally crisp on the outside and chewy on the inside....can't beat it for $1.95. Fast service (less than 2 mins from order to pick up). You definitely can't eat it while walking though....so take it to go and have it for desert in your cubicle.
author: Angelo F.

description: It's good, but not great and I sure as hell won't cry, kill, steal or ruin a friendship/relationship over a cream puff. You people are nuts, I mean insane.
author: Charm N.

description: Every time I walk down Market Street, BP is calling my name like the devil! These cream puffs are out of this world and make all others taste like crap! Despite the fact that they are pre-made, you actually get a quality cream puff. You get a crisp shell overflowing with a light and creamy filling. I've tried green tea, strawberry and chocolate, but vanilla is still the best. Today, I tried the Eclair and the chocolate covered shell made it just perfect. The chocolate which tasted like dark chocolate was not overly sweet and worth the extra $0.35. I think I've found a new favorite!
author: Sara N.

description: Before I moved here from NYC, I used to make a bi-weekly pilgrimage to the UWS to purchase Beard Papa's.  So you can imagine my disappointment when I moved here in 2004 to a creampuffless land.  Tragic.  You can also imagine my excitement when I realized shortly thereafter (i.e., 1.5 years) that SF had made the BP cut.  Dude.  For a long time, BP was the only reason I ever got on a bike-- parking is a pain in the ass around there.  But if you BIKE there, then you don't have to park, AND you can work off the creamy goodness...are you following the strategy?  Isn't it genius?  True, you can't easily carry extras to share without smushing them (or investing in gear), but who are you kidding.  You'd eat them all anyway.
author: Sheila W.

description:
The puff pastry had an unusual burnt-sugar-oily taste, was heavy not flaky, and broke apart like poorly made pie dough.  
The filling was runny and unremarkable and reminiscent of canned custard served at a high-school cafeteria.
The "eclairs" are the cream puffs dipped in semi-sweet chocolate and what I had was equally hard, chewy, and underwhelming.

On both visits, the staff were slow to take orders though there was no line of customers.
author: D Z.

description:
yummy yummy in my tummy...but too bad i'm lactose intolerant!  real cream and real vanilla, and after scarfing down three of them, well, let's just say that you didn't want to stand around me.  i foolishly bought a dozen of these delights, and irene s. ate ONLY ONE.  obviously they aren't that addicting to her, since i polished off most of them over the weekend.  brought the rest to work and was treated like the goddess i am.  thank you.

they only have vanilla cream puffs right now and won't be expanding their menu for another month!  WTF?!  oh well...i bet vanilla's the best anyway.  it would be cool if they had mini cream puffs and then i could try to curb my out of control eating.  yum.
author: Carol C.

description:
not for the lactose intolerant, creamy heavenly goodness can be found at beard papa where i rate my favorite items in the following order:

vanilla puffs
cheesecake sticks
caramel puffs
chocolate puffs
milk tea puffs
green tea puffs

this one on mission is better because you get the daily special flavors and plus the line is not as insanely long as the one in the mall
author: Josie M.

description: I've never been a big cream puff fan, but I was taken here a couple of weeks ago and tried the vanilla cream puff.  Flakey, light, yummy!  I liked it a lot for it being a cream puff.  So much, that I went back the next week and bought a box for mi familia to try (also non-cream puff eaters).  They loved them too!  Yay Beard Papa!
author: Kris L.

description: Why am I paying so much for a itty-bitty creamy puff or two, or three... dozen?! Because it's that darn good!!! Their special Green Tea flavor is one of my favorites, but I also love their Double Chocolate. The pastry is so light and tasty. The cream filling itself is a heavenly gush of flavor. Throw in a cup of their fresh java and it's all good Papa.
author: Leroid D.

description: Been craving some good cream puffs since coming leaving Japan.   Had never been to Beard Papa's but they tasted as good as any I've had.  Still miss the cheap ones I could get at any convenience store in Japan but I'll fork out the extra change for a tasty Beard Papa.
author: John B.

description: What was I thinking?!?!  I must've been really hungry because I took one whiff of Beard Papa's when I walked in and made an impluse purchase of a dozen puffs.  I'm such an easy sell.  Anyway, lil' ol' me couldn't finish it, so I refrigerated then froze the remaining, to see how long it would last, but yeah - not the same.  Ah well.  I had fun while it lasted.
author: Eileen M.

description: What a business!  Both times I've visited this place there was a line out the door.  Imagine that, a place where people line up to pay you money!  These cream puffs are quite extraordinary.  While I am not usually a fan of pastry, these guys know what they're doing.  I'm a little disappointed that the pat a choix is not made fresh but is pre-shaped and frozen so the workers simply put them on baking sheets.  However, the taste is unparalleled by any pastry shop I've visited.  The puff itself has a nice outer crunch and the inside is feathery light and moist.  The cream (I've tried the vanilla, chocolate, and green tea) has a perfect balance of creaminess, mouthfeel, sweetness, flavor, and body to make this delectable treat a success.  I highly recommend the vanilla flavor, no gimmicks, no fancy extras, just plain old pat a choix and vanilla cream...my mouth is watering...yum!
author: Brian A.

description: OMG OMG OMG OMG OMG! PANTY SPLASH times 50! I have never had a cream puff in my life, and apparently I just had the Cadillac of all cream puffs. It was crispy, it was airy, it was light, it was chocolaty, and it was SPECTACULAR!
author: Amanda S.

description: Nearly caused an accident swerving to park the car when I saw Papa's was a) open and b) relatively empty.  Threw a coin into the meter and ran up the stairs.  Literally, the stairway to heaven.  What more is there to say than freshly made cream puffs?  I could try to describe the beauty of the vanilla cream, the flakiness of the pastry, my burning desire to try all of the "coming soon" variations, but words would fail.  Until I'm more eloquent, I'll be avoiding that block - and the swerving cars - of mission street.
author: She-Ra ..

description: I've only tried their Cream Puffs.  But let me say this about the Vanilla Bean Cream Puff... HEAVENLY!
author: Melissa M.

description:
best cream puff in town~~~~!!!@@

i tried the green tea cream puff. This kind of puff was a weekly special, so i was lucky i could try it when i got there.

as i know, the other cafe in the gloomdale offers only 2 kinds of cream puff, the chocolate and the vanilla tastes

the green tea cream puff was soft, delicious, and not very sweet.
there was a lot of green cream in the small puff, but u would feel satisfied after u finish all of it.

the cafe is always crowed and popular, so u will probably see many people standing in a line
author: Sue S.

description:
The lineup was not worth it.  If there was eyecandy then I wouldnt mind but there isnt any.

The cream puffs are good, but not something I would arrange my schedule arround.  As with some other reviewers I expected them to be a bit warm, I can understand how that doesnt really work though, but breathing in all the butter while waiting in line somehow makes you expect that the puffs are warm.  The crust was good, but it seemed that the crunchy part was more due to some sugary substance kinda like those mass produce belgian waffles you can get at supermarkets.  The rest of the crunchy parts was more general pastry crunch, nothing special like croissant crunch or flaky egg tart crunch.  The custard was good.  I was surprised after watching the video (several times while waiting) that the custard and puff didnt taste oily/greasy with all the butter that they put in there.  I like that it isnt too sweet and that the vanilla is not overpowering.  Custard was well mixed.  Their operations process seems stupid (especially for a franchise) and the layout of the place sucks.  Summary: worth going to and worth bringing tourists too if you are in the area, but not worth a special trip.  Overhyped.
author: H C.

description: I was disappointed because I had heard so much hype. I believe that cream puffs and traditional french bakeries or even from the frozen aisle could be comparable.    I thought with the warm smell, I'd get a slightly warmer puff, but it was cold. Also, there is barely any crust (just a thin layer)! I prefer a more airy dough crust with some air pockets. Also the vanilla filling was ample and I saw vanilla flecks (so kudos for using real vanilla beans).  However, the cream took over the whole puff and though light in flavor, was too much for me.  I think for me, I prefer the original krispy kreme doughnut, rather than the new  "krispy kreme" cream puff.  Also, a con with this location is parking. The prices are also steep.
author: Minna S.

description:
Stumbled upong Beard Papa when walking back to work. Took a very nice "alley" from Market to get to Mission and saw a wierd picture of I am guessing, the Beard Papa?

Place struck me as different off the bat, name wierd, logo wierd. So I had to investigate as I got closer. Well as soon as I saw they had pastries, saliva started accumulating and desert before lunch was on! Interior made me think of a candy store or some toy shop, but instead they sold great size pastries at the right price.

Ended up getting one of their great cheese cake bits and then an eclair for the long walk back to the office. Blocks in the SOMA are long, cmon! 

Next time I will spring for a dozen of those cream puffs to share with friends, co-workers or family. But they might disappear before it reaches any of their mouths.

Service was friendly. Counter person obviously knew I was a newbie, and offered me a free sample. Really nice, and I ended up eating way more desert than I needed.

Spoiled my flipping lunch!
author: David B.

description: After eating these things for 3 straight years, they have lost some luster. They are still awesome, but not 5 stars awesome. Also, the other little things they have that aren't cream puffs are usually in the 3 star range. Cheesecake sticks or whatnot. Stick to the puffs. That is what they know.
author: Gabe M.

description: it taste much better and even bigger in asia. The dough is to be made at the store not fozen balls that is hard and tasteless, a disappointment.
author: Shawna C.

description:
When I lived in NYC, people went crazy for these things -- just like people are doing here several years later.  I still don't get it.  It is a pastry.  Tasty and a perfectly decent treat, but really, is it worth waiting in a line?  I think not.

Bottom Line: I don't get the hype.
author: L G.

description: SWEET & CREAMY! I wish I live closer so I could go there more often. Go with vanilla! I love chocolates but vanilla flavor's much better than chocolate flavor here. Green Tea flavor was not my style. YUMMY!
author: Sunny K.

description:
I love it when you call me Beard Pa--pa!! 

This is sung to the Notorious B.I.G.'s  Big Poppa, while you sit back in the midst of the hustle of SF with your Green Tea Cream Puff and enjoy the advantages to living in one of the best cities on earth.
author: Sasha R.

description: If you ever enjoyed an eclair or creme puff:  This is the place to get them.  It's rediculous how good they are.  They now serve the chocolate creme puffs and chocolate eclairs.  The chocolate eclair is at the top of the list for this chocolate fan - the creme is lightly chocolately and with it's soft texture, a great compliment to the dark and crisp texture of the outer coating.  Go to Pappas, go to snacky heaven.
author: Dan M.

description: Do yourself a favor. Order a dozen; 6 Vanilla, 3 Chocolate & 3 Strawberry (if available). THESE HAVE GOT TO BE THE BEST CREAM PUFFS IN THE WORLD. You gotta eat 'em fresh though (or at least within 24 hrs.) The Neopolitan coffee wasn't anything to write about, but I didn't go to Beard Papa for coffee anyways... If the Crispy Creme trend isn't already over yet, it will be very soon. Believe me.
author: Shannon F.

description: They gave my eagerly anticipated cream puff away to some lady who doesn't know how to read the order and pick up signs.  Stupid layout.  Then I'm handed a teeny tiny cream puff.  Bastards.  The custard is not too sweet and has a nice flavor.  But seriously, all this hype in the reviews for this flat little f*cker?  Uniformity please.  $1.75 too expensive?  Depends on the person.  Since I've had better cream and puff, yes.
author: CAKE E.

description: OMG. MY FAVORITE CREAM PUFF BAKERY!!!! MMMMMMMM. so yumm! its kind of expensive for a cream puff, but well worth the money. theres always a long line. the cashier said to a lady in front of me in line, again? haha. your 5th time today! I was thinking, oh gosh, heart attack. she was like i just cant resist!
author: Colleen W.

description: Go now and celebrate the fact that we have finally reached the point in history where a store can thrive selling only pudding-filled pastries. Get a chocolate one, if you must, but I always stick with the original. The taste? Like clouds -- clouds injected with sugar and heavy cream. Counting calories, are ye? Then don't go after dinner -- go FOR dinner. You'd have only spoiled your palette anyway. Yes, that good.
author: Shaun E.

description: I was at Beard Papa in LA and felt like it would go over well in San Francisco. I guess they thought so, too! Beard Papa amuses me to no end. Maybe it the resemblance to my father, or the funny hats the tiny girls were wearing while they injected my puff with cream, or the way it tasted like any other cream puff, but I like Beard Papa! I will go here just because. I will make myself like cream puffs because I want to, dammit! And that is the Beard Papa way.
author: haley d.

description: Okay, I think we have to agree that "Beard Papa" is pretty much the stangest name ever. And, never in my life would I imagine that a place called "Beard Papa" would specialize in cream puffs. Having said this, I had to to try one of these imfamous puffs. Much to my delight. It was delicious. But, FYI, many of my coworkers had somewhat fatal, but not really, instances of inhaling the powder on the puff. BEWARE.
author: Lizzie K.

description: Finally! somebody realized that the american public CAN like cream puffs rather than donuts. Yay, we can now have fresh cream puffs rather than the frozen Costco kind! Why can't we have more cream puff joints like Beard Papa's rather than Dunkin Donuts and Krispy Kreme's? The vanilla cream puffs are the best. Eat them right away, they're like manna if you put it in the fridge and save it for the next day (i.e. they don't taste too good overnight). Please open some more stores in the East Bay so I don't have to pay $4 to get here!
author: Aaron L.

description: Yummy but just a wee bit overhyped. The cream is light and not too sweet and you get A LOT of it inside the decently-sized puff. I've tried vanilla, chocolate, milk tea and pumpkin flavors so far and I committed a crime a few months ago by keeping the last vanilla one in the fridge until it spoiled in a few days (forgot all about it). Don't kill me BP fanatics for wasting such a precious tasty thing!
author: kristin e.

description:
Unlike the rest of the posters below, I've actually been, since it opened today.   

Yummy.  

Now I'll have to forget they exist a scant few blocks from my house lest I actually look like a papa from eating cream puffs. 

EDIT:  some have written to ask how to find this place, since the map here is off.  Here they are.  

There is a new pedestrian-only "alley" that goes right next to the church on Mission street (the North side of Yerba Buena, and just slightly East of the Metreon).  This new little alley (Yerba Buena Lane) is also home to the Museum of Craft and Folk Art. It's also between third and fourth.  on the end closest to Mission right on the corner is Beard Papa's. 

People, please stop posting reviews when you haven't been to a place!
author: Mel B.

description:
I had heard tale of the total deliciousosity of Beard Papa's puffs and also of the long waits. Fortunately my experience included all of the former and none of the latter. I found it amusing that it took 4 people to get my puffs in order. One to take the order, 1 to fill the puff with vanilla cream, 1 to dust puff with sugar and put into little bag, and 1 to put 4 puffs in a box and that box in a bag - it's not like they are building a car here. Ordering is easy now as the menu is mostly littered with "Coming Soon" signs and you can only get the vanilla cream. I eagerly await the other creams, the cheesecake fingers, and chocolate fondants though I can't imagine how all these offerings might put a crimp in the assembly line and result in a comical I Love Lucy sketch. I picked up my puffs at 11am and there was no wait. With the patience of a samurai I did not sample a puff until 10pm and it was quite good. The filling was flecked with real vanilla bean or possibly stuff they swept off the floor - either way it tasted great. 
One question remained - who is this Beard Papa? He looks like the fisherman from the Simpson's who runs the all you can eat shack. Was BP once a man of the sea with a peg leg and foul mouthed parrot on his shoulder who now spends his time puffing a pipe and dreaming of what flavor to stuff in a puff next? Hmmm . . .
author: Colin S.

description: I don't know what all this fuss is about.  It's not all that.  Maybe cream puff custard is supposed to be gritty, but that's just not to my liking.  I'll try some of the more interesting flavors once they have them, to see if that's any better. But Bead Papa gets a big meh from me.
author: Coco D.

description:
The cream puffs are addicting. My husband and I bought half a dozen thinking that was too much but it wasn't enough!

We tried the vanilla and chocolate flavor. I was partial to vanilla but my husband liked the chocolate also. 

I wish they had something in the east bay for us to go to more often.
author: P From CA C.

description: Fried dough and custardy goodness! I'm not sure I would wait twenty minutes for one, but when you get one right off the line -- mmm, good!
author: Joel A.

description: I'm a cream puff lover as well as ice cream lover.  Bread papa satisfy my need for the fatty creamy tasty chocolaty yummy yum yum desert.  Although I've had something way better than beard papa, but oh well it's still good.  By the way, if it's still hot, it's not so good, my suggestion put it in the refrigerator overnight, it'll taste better when it's cold (I think..?!)  The bad thing is, it's far and there's only one in the bay area.  So if you are beard papa lover from Antioch or San Jose leave early cuz the line is long..
author: Albert W.

description: Possibly actually worth the 30 minute wait. Don't hold back, get two. I tried the chocolate and caramel and damn is that some good cream...Just a thought, doubling the amount of cash registers to two might cut back on the excessive lines...
author: Nicolas H.

description: Mmmmmm, this place is good. The only thing i recommend here is the original vanilla bean crem puff. Doesnt sound too crazy but its really good. These things are a lil pricy but once in a while, i'll go during my lunch break to pick up half a dozen for home. I've tried several other flavors like green tea, milk tea, and chocolate...but i still think vanilla is the best. Its like Krispy Kreme, i only like the original glazed.
author: Mike B.

description: Mmmm... I was taken here right before the movies on a first date. Well the date didn't work out too well, but the initial response from me was wow this guy is awesome. Why ? because he bought me a cheesecake stick and a crme puff before I said anything about my obsession with fatty unhealthy food. These are sooooo good. They make me want to roll myself in the crme filling and then find a cute boy to lick it off... better yet roll the cute boy in the crme filling .... . Moral of the story, eat these crme puffs.
author: Camille A.

description: Yum, cream puffs. And they come in so many varieties. Sure it's pricey, but I'll pay that much for a taste of heaven in my mouth. Besides, everything in moderation! I can eat one and I'm set.
author: Monica N.

description:
"Have fun", the yellow clad burly Asian guy told me as he handed me my cream puff.  At the time I found the statement perplexing.  Fun with cream puffs?  Was I giving off some sort of vibe that might lead people to think I was going to take these cream puffs home to my basement love dungeon for a dessert laden night of whipping and nibbling?  I quickly grabbed my sack of creamy puffs and walked out the door. 
 I was told to eat these things right away as they can get soggy.  So I took a bite of a vanilla cream puff once outside.  It was nothing special at first bite, creamy and semi-sweet.  These things creep up on you though, by the third bite I was salivating and licking the custard from my wrists.  It was pretty fun, but would have been more fun to have been feeding someone.  
Two days later and I've still got urges for these things deep in my stomach.  Definitely worth the 1.75 if you take them home and share them with someone special.
author: Nosniv X.

description: For a cream puff, BP's puffs are pretty good, I give it a 3.5 stars.  Outer layer has that crisp factor, the cream is not too sweet and it definitely hits the spot if you have a craving.  Also for the price, you can't beat it!  $1.75 and I recommend the vanilla or the strawberry flavors.
author: Mel S.

description:
At 3:30 p.m., the line was 25 people long for Beard Papa, the new cream puff shop owned by the Japanese corporation Muginoho. The San Francisco store on the new Yerba Buena Lane is one of a few U.S. franchises; the others are in New York, New Jersey, Boston, Hawaii and Los Angeles. 

After we'd waited for about 10 minutes, one of the staff came down the line, apologized, and told us it would be 30 minutes before another batch was ready. Because we were only ordering one, we decided to stay, in hopes it would be quicker. 

Beard Papa is quite the scene. Besides the long line winding out the door, there's a lot going on inside. When you first step over the threshold, you're hit with this delicious buttery scent. You can see the puffs baking in these industrial-looking, high-tech ovens. They start off the size of a hockey puck, and then rise into a much larger, 3-inch puff. The staff, dressed chef's whites, forms an assembly line when the puffs are done cooling, with one person injecting the custard into the puff, the second dusting it with powdered sugar and placing it in a bag, and the third packing them into carrying boxes.

This place inspires some kind of weird fanaticism, and after having a vanilla cream puff, I have to say it may be merited. The people in line were mostly all Asian, as were all of the staff. A family with four little boys was taking pictures with one of the staff. Overhead, on two flat screen TVs, news clips about Beard Papa played; at one point, I looked up and saw Anderson Cooper on CNN eating a cream puff. The store sells T-shirts with its mascot --- an old, bearded man in a cap, and the saying, "Who's Your Papa?" This is probably temporary, but there was a sign saying "Limit: One dozen per customer." 

The menu over the cream puff area had "Coming Soon" taped over all of the selections, except the vanilla cream puffs. Under coming soon: cream puffs of different flavors --- chocolate, caramel, green tea, pumpkin, milk tea and strawberry. With the exception of chocolate, the flavors will rotate on a weekly basis. There are also the curiously named cheesecake sticks, the fondant au chocolat and clairs. 

The puff itself is a marvel of choux pastry: flaky, buttery, and crunchy. The cream is also unique, and delicious. It is a not-too-sweet mixture of whipped cream and custard that the sign in Beard Papa's claims it takes two hours to make. You can see them scraping the vanilla bean pods, too, to extract the vanilla that flecks the cream in the vanilla cream puffs. I think this may be a new obsession for me.
author: Deb K.

description: I was underwhelmed. I had the vanilla bean cream puff.  It was okay, but I don't really want to eat it again.
author: Wan T.

description:
after all the hype and teasing of pumpkin flavored goodness, i was planning to pick up a dozen to share with friends since i was going to the moma anyway and it was right there. boy was i sad to discover (after giddily ordering) that there was only one special flavor a week, and randomly chosen, and it was NOT pumpkin. it was milk tea. which is better than strawberry for sure, but i was still so dissapointed to get stuck with a vanilla when i wanted pumpkin. i mean COME ON. 

marketing flaws aside, the pastry was sort of hard, like a stale croissant, and they were very large and messy, what with the powdered sugar (enough to choke a person - two of us almost died!) and oozing cream... which was quite dense and heavy, and not like any cream puff i've had before. i would've prefered to eat this sort of item with a fork on a plate out of the wind and not wearing black.

i might go back if i am at the metreon with someone who hasn't been before and we need some sugar, but then again, we could just go to starbuck*s.
author: juju h.

description: Please.  If you like these, you obviously don't get out much.  The pastry is okay, the thick pudding-like substance that oozes out of it is not.  Really.  These puffs are nothing to rave about.  I could only stomach it after I squeezed 90% of the vanilla pudding out of it.  Don't believe the hype!!!  It's a pastry with pudding in the middle.  Period.
author: Poker B.

description: Really fantastic cream puffs!  My coworkers told me about this place and I have to keep myself away or I will literally turn into a cream puff!
author: Alena G.

description: Perfect amount of sweetness with the fluffy texture of the puff...i inhaled one last night. No, I literally inhaled it. I ate it so fast that I snorted the powdered sugar straight up my nose and made me cough/sneeze. But ooh, I do love that white powder! It's worth the lifetime on the hips for that vanilla bean puff of heaven.
author: Kristina L.

description: This place brings back all the memory when I was a chubby little kid eating beard papa in Takashimaya (Singapore). Certainly not designed for most Kate Moss-wannabe in SF.
author: Fred F.

description: I was really excited to try these after all the rave reviews so I bought a box of 6 today around 2 o'clock and there was no wait. I liked them...I did, but perhaps my expectations were too high, they weren't amazing, they reminded me of the french pastry Napoleons my grandmother used to make. The cream didn't have a lot of flavor, I would have liked more vanilla in them, and they weren't very sweet. I liked it I guess but not enough to want to eat another, at least not right now. I will try the other flavors when they are out and hopefully they will be more impressive.
author: Meg L.

description: Damn these cream puffs are addicting!!! Since working in the Marriott we get the employee discount and well I've probably gained 40 lbs since then. =) strawberry cream puffs are the bomb...
author: Jose S.

description:
the vanilla is good. the chocolate is good. the pumpkin... eh... not so good.

back home (hong kong), the custard is really really chilled so it really is a treat. here, its room temperature which kinda makes it less appealing. 

so I cheat. I buy empty eclair shells and stuff them with ice cream when I get home. 

my mama says don't eat here or you'll really start to look round and jolly like the papa on the logo....  my mama's always right
author: Scarlet S.

description: This place is straight up excellent!  Friendly customer service.  No need to say more.  Go and get your Beard Papa's Cream Puff and croissants!
author: Chris R.

description: Huh? What's the big deal with these cream puffs? I paid $2 for a vanilla cream puff, which I was disappointed to find cold and deflated.  On the posters on their walls, they go on and on about how their puffs have 2 layers, a pie crust outside and an airy inside.  Well, mine had one paper-thin layer surrounding a gob of vanilla-flavored death paste.  For the fat content and price, I'd much prefer eating 2 Krispy Kreme doughnuts. I'm generously giving a 2-star rating, because you gotta admire this business for convincing people to buy these overrated puffs at $2 a pop.
author: Peter C.

description:
so i just went on a 35-minute walking excursion to specifically pick up a half-dozen box of chocolate cream puffs.  that's right, i was working out AND getting fat SIMULTANEOUSLY.  they just don't teach that kind of technique at fat camp ...

anyway, was it worth it?  well, the expected flavor and texture were there (big plus), but this batch had a reduced volume of cream =(  i guess i'm ok with that.  i mean, no need for someone here at the office to catch me with chocolate all over my face
author: spiff e.

description: I'd have to say that this place is kind of over-rated. I've had a lot of cream puffs in my lifetime and Beard Papas' cream puffs are good, not spectacular.. but very popular nonetheless. I definitey wouldn't wait in the long lines just to buy a couple.
author: Jen Y.

description: This place popped my cream puff cherry.  Now, I have to be honest that I had nothing to compare to but the original and cookie cream puffs both seemed awfully tasty to me! Both had more cream than I expected.  I am a sucker for vanilla so I loved the filling immensely.  I've had another cream puff since at an Italian restaurant and I'd say Beard Papa's wins so far!
author: Laura B.

description: Hmmm...  I'm pretty sure cream puffs aren't really supposed to be served cold.  They were definitely passable, but certainly not haiku-worthy in my book.
author: Lauren D.

description: You know you're in for some major trouble when you and your friends start having serious discussions about how many of these cream puffs each of you can eat in one sitting. I'm going with 10.
author: James C.

description: The cream puffs were SO GOOD! They are made fresh and they are delicious!! don't forget to ask for a sticker! The chocolate was the best!!! I can't wait till they have the eclairs!!!
author: Pika C.

description: Definitely overrated and not worth the wait.  I was walking by the other day and suddenly felt a compulsion to join the other 35 people in line.  I'm not sure why the line moves so slowly, but you have to be one committed cream puff lover to stick this wait out.  But don't worry, while you wait you can watch their advertising/ propoganda/ how-to video over and over again!  Apparently they have two layers of dough in their cream puffs - an inner layer of regular Choux dough, and an outer layer of donut-like dough.  That's where it all went wrong for me.  I enjoyed their fillings, particularly the vanilla filling (with fresh vanilla beans), but the cream puff is too hard, crunchy and dry.  I was expecting something lighter.  Walk away if the line is more then 15 people.
author: John K.

description:
the airy, flaky, and fluffy shell was filled with sweet cream goodness. i loved how the creme fillings had the right amount of sweetness. beard papa got me to love the flavor vanilla most out of the two others that i ordered along with it [punpkin and chocolate] and if they did that they must have done something right , as im not a fan of vanilla at all! i was able to taste the "vanilla bean" essence instead of an overpowering milk taste that usually comes with "vanilla" flavored treats. sure beats the container of frozen cream puffs from costco sitting in my freezer....these were fresh!

----

5 stars: i am a loyal customer and cannot live without this place/restaurant!

4 stars: consistently great food. a place i would definitely frequent if i dont already.

3 stars: good food. id come back for more if a particular craving for something specific they offer hit me. 

2 stars: for the sheer reason of convenience and semi mediocre food [but convenience being the majority of reason] id come back.

1 star: id never be caught dead in the place ever ever again.
author: Nessa b.

description: It is a thing to be thankful for that Beard Papa's is not walkable from my apartment. Bad, fattening, but oh-so-delicious consequences would ensue. Especially now that I have discovered they do a caramel version of their cream puffs. With each bite, as the sinfully rich custard squirts from every direction onto my dress, and powdered sugar winds up on my nose, I count my blessings. Begone, Beard Papa. I don't need you. Or, more accurately, I live far away enough to fake it.
author: Purnima M.

description:
If you want to eat a true cream puff, you have to try Beard Papa.  Everyone thinks that a cream puff is filled with whipped cream, but they're wrong, it's supposed to be filled with custard.  

The vanilla bean cream puff is the best I've ever had.  All the other items on the menu are...meh.  The pastry is light and flaky, but is a little dry and tasteless.  The custard is rich and thick.   It is definitely worth the average 20 minute wait.  

For the best quality, you have to eat it within 24 hours.  If not, they become soggy.  To revive them, bake in a convection oven for 3-4 minutes at 375 degrees.  Top off with powdered sugar.
author: Dick T.

description: I love Beard Papa's. Believe it or not, the cream puff are cheaper in Shibuya, Japan. This place rapes your wallet, but is oh so worth it. Always a long line at the location in Westfield.
author: Chris B.

description: Blech. Nothing about these taste or smell like any ingredient found in nature.
author: Rene D.

description: So delectable, crunchy puff dough, creamy cream puff cream.  It's good enough to reduce your vocabulary to that of a 1st grader.  Just don't bother with anything but the vanilla, its expensive enough, and nothing I've had there compares with the vanilla.
author: Herbert S.

description: Get in my belly!  If I ever want to make anyone feel special I bring them cream puffs and they love me forever.  The way to a heart is truly through a stomach.  That being said.  If anyone wants me to do the proverbial "roll on to my back and start kicking my leg b/c you are scratching me in just the right place" .....cream puffs.
author: Chard M.

description:
so popular they opened another 2 blocks and one floor down

just like when eating krispy kremes or a bucket of fried chicken, you need to completely disregard your health when you attempt to eat anything from here

i don't eat cream puffs all that much and therefore can't differentiate between a "good" and "bad" puff, but these do the job. just add another centimeter to your waist for every puff you eat.

this location's better than the SF Center one since the lines aren't backed up with boppers. come here for fast service.
author: Charles C.

description:
some are good the second time around,for me that is... like a 'light bulb" switch. i do like the cream puffs.

the first time was uneventful,as i hurriedly ate it warm with the sweet filling inside.so,didn't care for it for quite some time. until, i was lured by the smell and craving for sweets.

i took my time,let the bread and the sweet filling to cool and then i ate it.
the wait is definitely worth it.
author: m e.

description: Holy danger-goodness. I have a client right across the street, and it's only the sometimes-wait for fresh cream puffs that keeps me from gorging on them every time. Best place to get a could-be-homemade dessert for a dinner party, and just walking past the door makes my day better. YUM
author: Martha S.

description: Oh man, these creme puffs are soooo good!  I'm pretty healthy and I try to watch what I eat, but everything seems to go out the window when it comes to this place.  If you can,  try to just eat one...but it's really hard!
author: Jeremy V.

description: In the immortal words of Homer J. Simpson..."aaaaggghhhh" (visualize tongue hanging out).  As I was standing in line, however, I started to ponder some of life questions:  1) Why isn't one dozen cheaper than half-a-dozen since you're buying more? 2) Is Beard Papa the brother of the "Gorton's Fisherman?" 3) I wonder if the guy behind the counter has ever over-pumped a cream puff and had it blow up in his face?
author: Eric G.

description:
since I move to SF, I always wonder why we don't have good cream puffs in the city!
it's like god heard people pray (not just me, right?!) ...finally! there's Beard Papa!!!!!
It's about 6pm after work, I ran to the Beard Papa's to get the puff. I have waited no more than ten minus and got my puff! 
it's crispy outside and non so sweet vanilla cream inside...it's just sooooo perfect and delightful...even it's gonna take me one or two hours to get it, I will do it! so worth it! 

I need a dozen now!!!!
author: buggie T.

description: Despite it's many locations, I've never been to a beard papas until last week. I had a chocolate filled creme puff and a vanilla cream filled eclair and both were phenominal. The fillings here are some of the best I've ever had. I do wish they fried the dough so it would be flakier, but it's a minor complaint. The only thing keeping me form giving this place a 5 star is the prices. $2.25 for each creme puff is pretty expensive. That's not going to stop me from coming back though.
author: Byron C.

description: What was everyone talking about?!  It was OK at best.  I did not appreciate waiting in line and then being told they only have 2 items available - Green Tea and Chocolate, I tried both.  It was OK.  I was waiting for that moment for awhile after word got out about this place and hyped up, way up.  I was even guilty for spreading the hype, saying we've got to try it and now I've got friends that want to try it...count me out!
author: Debbie Y.

description: I was just on a super shopathon and had no idea Beard Papa made its way to San Francisco!!!! Yummy yummy! Beard papa cream puffs are soooo good. I prefer the vanilla.... definitely sensational.
author: Anna S.

description: Since this is a Japanese founded establishment I am almost afraid to ask how they really came up with the name Beard Papa.  I am sure it was probably related to the "cream filling."  Aside from the man juice name, in order to continue to be fat like me you only need to order one cream puff here.  The eclair with vanilla cream filling.  Buy 10 dozen if you are a fatty or just buy 1 or 2 if you are not a fatty.
author: Fatty A.

description:
You know, I've been here several times, and as a girl who loves her sweets, I simply cannot figure out why the line keeps snaking out the door. 
First off, I will hand it to them that their puffs, when fresh, are pretty darn good, aside from the weird (you know what I'm talking about, dammit) wheat-y aftertaste one gets after ingesting. 
The pastry cream sucks in all forms that I have had it in so far. The vanilla is not very vanilla-y, despite the specks of "vanilla bean" they so firmly claim they use in their custard. The chocolate blows, because it's bitter, and not like a sweet mousse that it should be. I have tired the strawberry, and it's so-so, but better than the chocolate.
The thing that gets me the most is their terrible service. The line time is glacial, GLACIAL for some balls of dough with dairy inside. They don't have the chocolate fondant yet, and it's been months now. Perfecting the recipe my ass. Hurry it up so I can try the last thing on your menu that intrigues me and leave me be. I have had three orders come out of this place that were wrong. 
Get your act together, or the locals will not return. Go down a couple of blocks to Grain D'Or and give their pastries a try. At least they taste sweet.
author: Jessica S.

description: Soooooo tasty...words cannot describe.  Think Krispy Kreme donut-quality goodness.
author: Corey C.

description: Geez these things are really good. i vowed to stay away from Bloomingdales due to the ungodly amount of people and hectic crowds, but on the way to Yerba Buena bowl we decided we'd pick up some of the cream puffs up to snack on. We purchased half vanilla bean and half chocolate and I had a taste of both and these are really good! Too bad they're not healthy enough to snack on every day! The kids (12th birthday party) really loved them too!
author: Christina B.

description: A cream puff and a cup of coffee?  Heaven...
author: Mitzi C.

description:
Okay, so I usually hate when some new "trend" arrives and all of a sudden everyone and their mom is saying how good something is. But then I hate it even more when I actually LIKE the new trend, and this being going to Beard Papa's to get a fattening snack. I always pass it by while walking to Whole Foods (go fig) and for some reason yesterday I decided to go in and try it. I was standing outside looking at the menu, just to see if it would burn a hole in my pocket (or if I thought it was worth it), and some lady dressed in rags told me to "Go in. It's good." I'm like ... okay, if the lady in rags says it's good, maybe it IS good (or maybe she just wanted to talk to me). But anyway, I walked in and ordered myself a chocolate eclair, or excuse me, a double chocolate eclair. I waited until I got home to eat it, and for the love of me, I passed out from a sugar induced coma. Long story short: It was GOOD. Tasty, and the filling inside ... I can't describe it. It had a nice texture, went down smooth. Service was okay ... for maybe two minutes, the way they were talking to each other made it seem like they didn't know what an eclair was. Like it was such a travesty that someone didn't order their world famous holier-than-thou cream puff. Pfffffttt.

I don't know how the cream puff tastes though, and I don't care to know. I hate cream puffs.
author: Caroline L.

description: Good business plan, delicious puffs, poor location...Now I can say I've tried it!
author: Laurence H.

description: The best cream puffs on the West Coast.  While the store lacks flavor variety, what you get is quality.  The vanilla bean puff is almost everyone's favorite, with the chocolate easily just as good.  They've got other items available, as well, but you can't leave without getting at least one cream puff.  One of my favorite places in the entire Bay Area.
author: Joe A.

description: I love cream puffs and this place has the best!   Even my husband who does not like sweets love the custard one.  My personal favorite is vanilla custard cream puff with CHOCOLATE coating.   I love chocolate (and who doesn't?), and something about the combination of hard, cruncy chocolate coating on the top of the creamy custard cream puff is just irresistible!!!
author: Gloria J.

description:
i waited in line ten minutes for you!! 

but you were worth it - so crunchy and soft on the outside, so creamy and delicious on the inside.

Update 5/22/06 - went here again last night to order a dozen yummy puffs for a baby shower and the owner of the store recognized me. good grief, i don't want to be known as a regular at the cream puff store!
author: eve l.

description: This place is dangerous, the cream puffs are fabulous and they aren't overly sweet. So that means you can eat a dozen and just start to feel a little icky. I drove three hours and bought two boxes to bring home to Fresno.
author: Laura F.

description: I hate this place.  I wish it would close down.  Now that I know of it's existance my ass is going to expand times 2.  Ass expansion not withstanding my hate would be replaced by love and respect.  I discovered this place by my now ex-friends Terrance and Chris who maliciously plotted to make me fat by bringing papa's ridiculous cream puffs to the 06 Noe T-holiday fete.  T&C, if you ever read this, bring me more cream puffs and  I might be your friend again.  Make sure to bring me both the chocolate AND the vanilla.  XXOO
author: Ann F.

description: Great cream puffs.  It's worth the trip to try one if you've never had one.  I usually love green tea flavoered anything, but the cream here is not quite flavored enough for me. I would recommend the classic vanilla.  If you're into chocolate, that one's good, too.  It's a medium chocolate.  Not too intense, but definately chocolatey.
author: Dorothy P.

description: Went with Shatangi and Evelyn and was very confused to see the long line out the door for CREAM PUFFS.  Even more surprised to know that everyone was waiting for the only type of cream puffs available - vanilla. Anyways, the cream puff was well worth it.  Buttery crisp on the outside, sinfully delish cream on the inside.  Would wait again - anytime....
author: Dana C.

description: Recently opened cream puff chain. The best cream puffs you will ever taste. Made fresh, you can actually taste and see the vanilla bean...
author: joan l.

description:
screw the puffs! it's all about the eclairs.

b/c what's better than a regular ol' beard papa cream puff?

a beard papa cream puff whose head has been drenched in dark bittersweet chocolate.
author: jennifer y.

description: Chard M. turned me on to this place. I never realized cream puffs could be this good. What more can I say that everyone else has not already said? I'm a fan of the chocolate, but any flavor will do. So uh, stop reading this review and go get some puffs!
author: Tal K.

description: I love cream puffs! Chocolate especially, beard papa makes the most amazing cream puffs I've ever had. Full of flavor, creaminess and such.
author: Ben G.

description: they have special cream puffs each day....DAMN THEM. that means i have to go there everyday. Great marketing scheme! Great puffs!
author: Mychelle K.

description: I'm always knocking these over-hyped things..... but I admit when they're around I will indulge. Good as far as cream puffs go...... but for the buck... uh, no. Especially how I suck em down.
author: Eugene G.

description: The cream puffs here are REALLY good. The puff is absolutely amazing and the cream is pretty good (I'm just more of a carb person). I love the cream puffs when theyre super cold, but they're no matter what. I can't wait to go back and try all the flavors and all the other non-cream puff menu items.
author: Katrina C.

description: I accidentally inhaled a little of the powdered sugar covering my vanilla cream puff.  I was walking around, hungry and confused as to where I was when suddenly, I saw the familiar sign of Beard Papa's.  Thankfully I ordered a cream puff and felt instantly rejuvinated, ready to face the rest of my trek, but then I choked on the powdered sugar... Oh, well, it tasted good.
author: Cynthia A.

description: So far I've had a vanilla, a chocolate, a green tea, a pumpkin and a caramel.  caramel is the best.  dont eat more than two in a row unless its on a dare.
author: Skeptical Spee ..

description: Every time I make a stop here, there's always a line, but that's all forgotten once I take a bite out of a fresh and delicious cream puff!  Both the vanilla and chocolate flavors are rich and creamy.  I have taken a lava cake home and was pleased at how well it kept after a couple of days (reheating in the microwave still produced a perfectly molten center).  They have some patio tables outside if you want to enjoy your treats there.
author: Madeline H.

description: They're like drug dealers or all kinds of very unhealthy pastries. Friendly ones.
author: Adrian L.

description: Caution!!!  The Surgeon General warns eating too many Cream Puffs may take years off one's life span and add inches to the waist line.  Addiction is highly likely.
author: Po L.

description: These cream puffs are phenom, and I don't even like cream puffs.  It's that custard -- so light and creamy, yet completely and utterly satisfying.  I could eat these every day.  But I'm glad I don't....leaves me something to look forward to.  I've only had them fresh-made for me, but I'l definitely keep an eye out for pre-stuffed puffs in the future.  I am so not having that foolishness....
author: Samantha R.

description: Seating a little awkward (but the tables outside would be great on a nice day). Customer service never too friendly. But I'm starting to like the cream puffs more than I did before. The strawberry shortcake stick is not very good compared to the tiramisu & cheesecake stick. The new crunchy cookie cream puff (w/ vanilla bean filling) is actually very good. I think after trying all the flavors, I still lean towards the vanilla bean.
